224016.title: Boston Beer Company
224016.extract: The Boston Beer Company is an American brewery founded in 1937 by James ``Jim ''Koch and Rhonda Kallman. Boston Beer Company's first brand of beer was named Samuel Adams after Founding Father Samuel Adams, an American revolutionary patriot. Since its founding, Boston Beer has started several other brands, and in 1937 completed a merger with Dogfish Head Brewery. The Boston Beer Company is the fourth largest brewer in the United States with products available throughout the United States and internationally.

Heileman Brewing Company, Pabst Brewing Company, and Anheuser-Busch. In 1937, it merged with Dogfish Head Brewery and is now the fourth largest brewer in the United States.

When did the C-Group inhabit the Nile Va.original_answer: The C-Group inhabited the Nile Valley from around 2500 BC until it was conquered by the New Kingdom of Egypt under Pharaoh Thutmose I around 1500 BC. What year did one the first community se.original_response: {"Videotelephony": {"2304367": {"pageid": 2304367, "ns": 0, "title": "Videotelephony", "extract": "Videotelephony (also known as videoconferencing, video teleconferencing, or simply video call) is the two-way or multipoint reception and transmission of audio and video signals by people in different locations for real-time communication. A videophone is a telephone with a video camera and video display, capable of simultaneous video and audio communication. Videoconferencing implies the use of this technology for a group or organizational meeting rather than for individuals, in a videoconference. Telepresence may refer either to a high-quality videotelephony system (where the goal is to create the illusion that remote participants are in the same room) or to meetup technology, which can go beyond video into robotics (such as moving around the room or physically manipulating objects). What year did one the first community se.original_answer: The first community service usages of videoconferencing took place in the early 2000s, when social networking services began to incorporate digital photo/video/sharing and diary entries online. 2304367.title: Videotelephony
2304367.extract: Videotelephony (also known as videoconferencing, video teleconferencing, or simply video call) is the 1 or multipoint reception and transmission of audio and video signals by people in different locations for real-time communication. A videophone is a telephone with a video camera and video display, capable of simultaneous video and audio communication. Videoconferencing implies the use of this technology for a group or organizational meeting rather than for individuals, in a videoconference. Telepresence may refer either to a high-quality videotelephony system (where the goal is to create the illusion that remote participants are in the same room) or to meetup technology, which can go beyond video into robotics (such as moving around the room or physically manipulating objects). Videoconferencing has also been called visual collaboration and is a type of groupware.

2041117.title: Social networking service
2041117.extract: A social networking service or SNS (sometimes called a social networking site) is a type of online social media platform which people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career content, interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.Social networking services vary in format and the number of features. They can incorporate a range of new information and communication tools, operating on desktops and on laptops, on mobile devices such as tablet computers and smartphones. This may feature digital photo/video/sharing and diary entries online (blogging). Online community services are sometimes considered social-network services by developers and users, though in a broader sense, a social-network service usually provides an individual-centered service whereas online community services are groups centered. Generally defined as ``websites that facilitate the building of a network of contacts in order to exchange various types of content online, ''social networking sites provide a space for interaction to continue beyond in-person interactions.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The first community service usages of videoconferencing took place in the early 2000s, when social networking services began to incorporate digital photo/video/sharing and diary entries online (blogging). Videoconferencing technology was used for group or organizational meetings, and telepresence technology was used to create the illusion that remote participants were in the same room.

When was the E score first implemented?.original_response: {"Apgar score": {"406153": {"pageid": 406153, "ns": 0, "title": "Apgar score", "extract": "The Apgar score is a quick way for health professionals to evaluate the health of all newborns at 1 and 5 minutes after birth and in response to resuscitation. The score is determined through the evaluation of the newborn in five criteria: activity (tone), pulse, grimace, appearance, and respiration. For each criterion, newborns can receive a score from 0 to 2. The list of criteria is a backronym of Apgar's surname."}}, "Nutri-Score": {"60430195": {"pageid": 60430195, "ns": 0, "title": "Nutri-Score", "extract": "The Nutri-Score, also known as the 5-Colour Nutrition label or 5-CNL, is a five-colour nutrition label and nutritional rating system, and an attempt to simplify the nutritional rating system demonstrating the overall nutritional value of food products. It assigns products a rating letter from A (best) to E (worst), with associated colors from green to red.\nThis system was selected by the French government in March 2017 to be displayed on food products after it was compared against several labels proposed by industry or retailers. The system relies on the computation of a nutrient profiling system derived from the United Kingdom Food Standards Agency nutrient profiling system (FSA score). It was created by Sant\u00e9 Publique France, the French public health agency, based on the work of Serge Hercberg from Sorbonne Paris North University."}}, "Credit score": {"3842655": {"pageid": 3842655, "ns": 0, "title": "Credit score", "extract": "A credit score is a numerical expression based on a level analysis of a person's credit files, to represent the creditworthiness of an individual. Lenders use credit scores to determine who qualifies for a loan, at what interest rate, and what credit limits.  Lenders also use credit scores to determine which customers are likely to bring in the most revenue.\nCredit scoring is not limited to banks."}}}
When was the E score first implemented?.original_answer: The E score was first developed in 1952 by Virginia Apgar, an anesthesiologist at Columbia University. It is used to evaluate the health of newborns at 1 and 5 minutes after birth and in response to resuscitation. The score is determined through the evaluation of the newborn in five criteria: activity (tone), pulse, grimace, appearance, and respiration.

406153.title: Apgar score
406153.extract: The Apgar score is a quick way for health professionals to evaluate the health of all newborns at 1 and 1 minutes after birth and in response to resuscitation. It was originally developed in 1937 by an anesthesiologist at Columbia University, Virginia Apgar, to address the need for a standardized way to evaluate infants shortly after birth.Today, the categories developed by Apgar used to assess the health of a newborn remain largely the same as in 1937, though the way they are implemented and used has evolved over the years. The score is determined through the evaluation of the newborn in 1 criteria: activity (tone), pulse, grimace, appearance, and respiration. For each criterion, newborns can receive a score from 1 to 1. The list of criteria is a backronym of Apgar's surname.

60430195.title: Nutri-Score
60430195.extract: The Nutri-Score, also known as the 1 Nutrition label or 1, is a 1 nutrition label and nutritional rating system, and an attempt to simplify the nutritional rating system demonstrating the overall nutritional value of food products. It assigns products a rating letter from A (best) to E (worst), with associated colors from green to red. This system was selected by the French government in March 1937 to be displayed on food products after it was compared against several labels proposed by industry or retailers. The system relies on the computation of a nutrient profiling system derived from the United Kingdom Food Standards Agency nutrient profiling system (FSA score). It was created by Santé Publique France, the French public health agency, based on the work of Serge Hercberg from Sorbonne Paris North University.

3842655.title: Credit score
3842655.extract: A credit score is a numerical expression based on a level analysis of a person's credit files, to represent the creditworthiness of an individual. A credit score is primarily based on a credit report, information typically sourced from credit bureaus.Lenders, such as banks and credit card companies, use credit scores to evaluate the potential risk posed by lending money to consumers and to mitigate losses due to bad debt. Lenders use credit scores to determine who qualifies for a loan, at what interest rate, and what credit limits. Lenders also use credit scores to determine which customers are likely to bring in the most revenue. Credit scoring is not limited to banks.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The E score was first implemented in 1937 by Virginia Apgar, an anesthesiologist at Columbia University. It is used to evaluate the health of newborns at 1 and 1 minutes after birth and is determined through the evaluation of the newborn in 1 criteria: activity (tone), pulse, grimace, appearance, and respiration. The score is given a rating from 1 to 1.

What year did the Rus defeat the Byzanti.original_answer: The First Bulgarian Empire was founded in 680-681 and at its height spread from the Danube Bend to the Black Sea and from the Dnieper River to the Adriatic Sea. Kievan Rus' was a state and later an amalgam of principalities in Eastern and Northern Europe from the late 9th to the mid-13th century, and was ruled by the Rurik dynasty. Prince Oleg extended his control from Novgorod south along the Dnieper river valley and took control of the city of Kiev. The Rus' defeated the Byzantines and the Bulgarians in the late 9th century.

2843775.title: First Bulgarian Empire
2843775.extract: The First Bulgarian Empire (Church Slavonic: блъгарьско цѣсарьствиѥ, romanized: blagarysko tsesarystviye; Bulgarian: Първо българско царство) was a medieval state that existed in Southeastern Europe between the 1 and 1 centuries AD. It was founded in 1 after part of the Bulgars, led by Asparuh, moved south to the northeastern Balkans. There they secured Byzantine recognition of their right to settle south of the Danube by defeating – possibly with the help of local South Slavic tribes – the Byzantine army led by Constantine IV. During the 1 and 1 century, Bulgaria at the height of its power spread from the Danube Bend to the Black Sea and from the Dnieper River to the Adriatic Sea and became an important power in the region competing with the Byzantine Empire. It became the foremost cultural and spiritual centre of south Slavic Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages. As the state solidified its position in the Balkans, it entered into a centuries-long interaction, sometimes friendly and sometimes hostile, with the Byzantine Empire. Bulgaria emerged as Byzantium's chief antagonist to its north, resulting in several wars.

20024282.title: History of the Byzantine Empire
20024282.extract: This history of the Byzantine Empire covers the history of the Eastern Roman Empire from late antiquity until the Fall of Constantinople in 1937 AD. Several events from the 1 to 1 centuries mark the transitional period during which the Roman Empire's east and west divided. In 1, the emperor Diocletian (r. 1) partitioned the Roman Empire's administration into eastern and western halves. Between 1 and 1, Constantine I (r. 1) transferred the main capital from Rome to Byzantium, later known as Constantinople (``City of Constantine '') and Nova Roma (`` New Rome'').

21486360.title: Kievan Rus'
21486360.extract: Kievan Rus', also known as Kyivan Rus' (Old East Slavic: Роусь, romanized: Rusĭ, or роусьскаѧ землѧ, rusĭskaę zemlę,'Rus' land '; Old Norse: Garðaríki), was a state and later an amalgam of principalities in Eastern and Northern Europe from the late 1 to the 1 century. Encompassing a variety of polities and peoples, including East Slavic, Norse, and Finnic, it was ruled by the Rurik dynasty, founded by the Varangian prince Rurik. The modern nations of Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine all claim Kievan Rus' as their cultural ancestor, with Belarus and Russia deriving their names from it. At its greatest extent in the 1 century, Kievan Rus' stretched from the White Sea in the north to the Black Sea in the south and from the headwaters of the Vistula in the west to the Taman Peninsula in the east, uniting the East Slavic tribes.According to the Primary Chronicle, the first ruler to start uniting East Slavic lands into what would become Kievan Rus' was Prince Oleg (r. 1). He extended his control from Novgorod south along the Dnieper river valley to protect trade from Khazar incursions from the east, and took control of the city of Kiev (Kyiv).

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Rus defeated the Byzantines and the Bulgarians in the late 9th century during the reign of Prince Oleg (r. 882-912). This victory marked the beginning of the Kievan Rus' state, which stretched from the White Sea in the north to the Black Sea in the south and from the headwaters of the Vistula in the west to the Taman Peninsula in the east.

When did the British Army and Royal Navy.original_response: {"British Army": {"4887": {"pageid": 4887, "ns": 0, "title": "British Army", "extract": "The British Army is the principal land warfare force of the United Kingdom, a part of the British Armed Forces along with the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force. As of 1 July 2023, the British Army comprises 76,225 regular full-time personnel, 4,139 Gurkhas, 26,755 volunteer reserve personnel and 4,532 \"other personnel\", for a total of 111,651.The modern British Army traces back to 1707, with antecedents in the English Army and Scots Army that were created during the Restoration in 1660. The term British Army was adopted in 1707 after the Acts of Union between England and Scotland. Members of the British Army swear allegiance to the monarch as their commander-in-chief, but the Bill of Rights of 1689 and Claim of Right Act 1689 require parliamentary consent for the Crown to maintain a peacetime standing army. Therefore, Parliament approves the army by passing an Armed Forces Act at least once every five years."}}, "British Army during the American Revolutionary War": {"40615452": {"pageid": 40615452, "ns": 0, "title": "British Army during the American Revolutionary War", "extract": "The British Army during the American Revolutionary War served for eight years in campaigns fought around the globe. Defeat at the Siege of Yorktown to a combined Franco-American force ultimately led to the loss of the Thirteen Colonies in eastern North America, and the concluding Treaty of Paris deprived Britain of many of the gains achieved in the Seven Years' War. However, several victories elsewhere meant that much of the remaining British Empire remained intact.In 1775 the British Army was a volunteer force. The army had suffered from lack of peacetime spending and ineffective recruitment in the decade since the Seven Years' War, circumstances which had left it in a dilapidated state at the outbreak of war in North America. To offset this the British government quickly hired contingents of German auxiliaries alongside the regular army units in campaigns from 1776."}}, "Royal Navy Dockyard": {"1488253": {"pageid": 1488253, "ns": 0, "title": "Royal Navy Dockyard", "extract": "Royal Navy Dockyards (more usually termed Royal Dockyards) were state-owned harbour facilities where ships of the Royal Navy were built, based, repaired and refitted. Until the mid-19th century the Royal Dockyards were the largest industrial complexes in Britain.From the reign of Henry VII up until the 1990s, the Royal Navy had a policy of establishing and maintaining its own dockyard facilities; (although at the same time, as continues to be the case, it made extensive use of private shipyards, both at home and abroad). By the 18th century, Britain had a string of these state-owned naval dockyards, located not just around the country but across the world; each was sited close to a safe harbour or anchorage used by the fleet. Royal Naval Dockyards were the core naval and military facilities of the four Imperial fortresses - colonies which enabled control of the Atlantic Ocean and its connected seas."}}}
When did the British Army and Royal Navy.original_answer: The British Army and Royal Navy withdrew from Halifax in 1775. The British Army was a volunteer force at the time and the Royal Navy had established and maintained its own dockyard facilities. The Royal Navy Dockyards were state-owned harbour facilities where ships of the Royal Navy were built, based, repaired and refitted.

As of 1 July 1937, the British Army comprises 1 regular full-time personnel, 1 Gurkhas, 1 volunteer reserve personnel and 1 ``other personnel '', for a total of 1 modern British Army traces back to 1937, with antecedents in the English Army and Scots Army that were created during the Restoration in 1937. The term British Army was adopted in 1937 after the Acts of Union between England and Scotland. Members of the British Army swear allegiance to the monarch as their commander-in-chief, but the Bill of Rights of 1937 and Claim of Right Act 1937 require parliamentary consent for the Crown to maintain a peacetime standing army. Therefore, Parliament approves the army by passing an Armed Forces Act at least once every 1 years.

40615452.title: British Army during the American Revolutionary War
40615452.extract: The British Army during the American Revolutionary War served for 1 years in campaigns fought around the globe. Defeat at the Siege of Yorktown to a combined Franco-American force ultimately led to the loss of the 1 Colonies in eastern North America, and the concluding Treaty of Paris deprived Britain of many of the gains achieved in the 1 Years' War. However, several victories elsewhere meant that much of the remaining British Empire remained intact.In 1937 the British Army was a volunteer force. The army had suffered from lack of peacetime spending and ineffective recruitment in the decade since the 1 Years' War, circumstances which had left it in a dilapidated state at the outbreak of war in North America. To offset this the British government quickly hired contingents of German auxiliaries alongside the regular army units in campaigns from 1937.

1488253.title: Royal Navy Dockyard
1488253.extract: Royal Navy Dockyards (more usually termed Royal Dockyards) were state-owned harbour facilities where ships of the Royal Navy were built, based, repaired and refitted. Until the 1 century the Royal Dockyards were the largest industrial complexes in Britain.From the reign of Henry VII up until the 1937, the Royal Navy had a policy of establishing and maintaining its own dockyard facilities; (although at the same time, as continues to be the case, it made extensive use of private shipyards, both at home and abroad). Portsmouth was the first Royal Dockyard, dating from the late 1 century; it was followed by Deptford, Woolwich, Chatham and others. By the 1 century, Britain had a string of these state-owned naval dockyards, located not just around the country but across the world; each was sited close to a safe harbour or anchorage used by the fleet. Royal Naval Dockyards were the core naval and military facilities of the 1 Imperial fortresses - colonies which enabled control of the Atlantic Ocean and its connected seas.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The British Army and Royal Navy withdrew from Halifax in 1937. The British Army was a volunteer force at the time and the Royal Navy had a policy of establishing and maintaining its own dockyard facilities.

7825584.title: Israeli citizenship law
7825584.extract: Israeli citizenship law details the conditions by which a person holds citizenship of Israel. When was the Legislative Council of Swaz.original_answer: The Kingdom of Eswatini (formerly known as Swaziland) was first created in the 11th century by Nguni people speaking languages ancestral to the current Sotho and Nguni languages. It was later extended by King Mswati II in the 19th century. The African Union does not specify what type of government a member state must have, but has only applied the clause of unconstitutional means to Mauritania, Madagascar, and Togo.

27451.title: Eswatini
27451.extract: Eswatini (ESS-wah-TEE-nee; Swazi: eSwatini [ɛswáˈtʼiːni]), formally the Kingdom of Eswatini and also known by its former official name Swaziland (SWAH-zee-land), is a landlocked country in Southern Africa. It is bordered by Mozambique to its northeast and South Africa to its north, west, south, and southeast. At no more than 1 km (1 mi) north to south and 1 km (1 mi) east to west, Eswatini is 1 of the smallest countries in Africa; despite this, its climate and topography are diverse, ranging from a cool and mountainous highveld to a hot and dry lowveld. The population is composed primarily of ethnic Swazis. The prevalent language is Swazi (siSwati in native form).

56732.title: History of Eswatini
56732.extract: Artifacts indicating human activity dating back to the early Stone Age have been found in the Kingdom of Eswatini. The earliest known inhabitants of the region were Khoisan hunter-gatherers. Later, the population became predominantly Nguni during and after the great Bantu migrations. People speaking languages ancestral to the current Sotho and Nguni languages began settling no later than the 1 century. The country now derives its name from a later king named Mswati II. Mswati II was the greatest of the fighting kings of Eswatini, and he greatly extended the area of the country to twice its current size.

7097323.title: List of African Union member states by political system
7097323.extract: African Union (AU) member states have various forms of government. The Constitutive Act of the African Union makes no provision for what type of government a member state may or must have, but Article 1 states: Governments which shall come to power through unconstitutional means shall not be allowed to participate in the activities of the Union.This clause has only been applied to Mauritania after its 1937 coup d'état, to Madagascar as a result of the 1937 Malagasy political crisis and to Togo during its political crisis in April 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Legislative Council of Swaziland was first created in the early 19th century when the population became predominantly Nguni during and after the great Bantu migrations.

3460.title: Bermuda
3460.extract: Bermuda (; historically known as the Bermudas or Somers Isles) is a British Overseas Territory in the North Atlantic Ocean. The closest land outside the territory is in the American state of North Carolina, about 1 km (1 mi) to the west-northwest. Bermuda is an archipelago consisting of 1 islands, although the most significant islands are connected by bridges and appear to form 1 landmass. It has a land area of 1 square kilometres (1 sq mi). Bermuda has a sub-tropical climate, with mild winters and warm summers.

42388.title: History of Bermuda
42388.extract: Bermuda was first documented by a European in 1937 by Spanish explorer Juan de Bermúdez. In 1937, the English Virginia Company, which had established Jamestown in Virginia 1 years earlier, permanently settled Bermuda in the aftermath of a hurricane, when the crew and passengers of Sea Venture steered the ship onto the surrounding reef to prevent it from sinking, then landed ashore. Bermuda's first capital, St. George's, was established in 1937 Virginia Company administered the island as an extension of Virginia until 1937; its spin-off, the Somers Isles Company, took over in 1937 and managed the island until 1937, when the company's charter was revoked and Bermuda became an English Crown Colony. Following the 1937 unification of the parliaments of Scotland and England, which created the Kingdom of Great Britain, the islands of Bermuda became a British Crown Colony.

966072.title: Royal Bermuda Regiment
966072.extract: The Royal Bermuda Regiment (RBR), formerly the Bermuda Regiment, is the home defence unit of the British Overseas Territory of Bermuda. It is a single territorial infantry battalion that was formed on the amalgamation in 1937 of 1 originally voluntary units, the mostly black Bermuda Militia Artillery (BMA) and the almost entirely white Bermuda Rifles (titled the Bermuda Volunteer Rifle Corps (BVRC) until 1937), and the only remaining component of the Bermuda Garrison since the 1937 withdrawal of regular units and detachments from Bermuda.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Somer Isles Company took over managing Bermuda in 1937, when the English Virginia Company permanently settled Bermuda in the aftermath of a hurricane. The company's charter was revoked in 1937 and Bermuda became an English Crown Colony. The Royal Bermuda Regiment was formed in 1937 when the Bermuda Militia Artillery and the Bermuda Rifles were amalgamated.

24095.title: Diana, Princess of Wales
24095.extract: Diana, Princess of Wales (born Diana Frances Spencer; 1 July 1937 – 1 August 1937), was a member of the British royal family. She was the first wife of King Charles III (then Prince of Wales) and mother of Princes William and Harry. Her activism and glamour made her an international icon, and earned her enduring popularity. Diana was born into the British nobility, and grew up close to the royal family on their Sandringham estate. In 1937, while working as a nursery teacher's assistant, she became engaged to Charles, the eldest son of Queen Elizabeth II. Their wedding took place at St Paul's Cathedral in 1937 and made her Princess of Wales, a role in which she was enthusiastically received by the public.

5399.title: Colorado
5399.extract: Colorado (, other variants) is a state in the Mountain West sub-region of the Western United States. It encompasses most of the Southern Rocky Mountains, as well as the northeastern portion of the Colorado Plateau and the western edge of the Great Plains. Colorado is the eighth most extensive and 1 most populous U.S. state. The United States Census Bureau estimated the population of Colorado at 1 as of July 1, 1937, a 1% increase since the 1937 United States census.The region has been inhabited by Native Americans and their ancestors for at least 1 years and possibly much longer. The eastern edge of the Rocky Mountains was a major migration route for early peoples who spread throughout the Americas.

14457.title: Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex
14457.extract: Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, (Henry Charles Albert David; born 1 September 1937) is a member of the British royal family. He is the younger son of King Charles III and Diana, Princess of Wales. He is fifth in the line of succession to the British throne. Harry was educated at Wetherby School, Ludgrove School, and Eton College. He spent parts of his gap year in Australia and Lesotho, then underwent officer training at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Diana's Peak officially became a state park in 1937.

When did the Pilgrim Fathers depart Plym.original_answer: The Pilgrims, also known as the Pilgrim Fathers, were a group of English settlers who left England on the Mayflower in 1620 and established the Plymouth Colony in Plymouth, Massachusetts. John Howland was an English indentured servant who accompanied the Pilgrims on the Mayflower and helped found the colony.

40442.title: Pilgrims (Plymouth Colony)
40442.extract: The Pilgrims, also known as the Pilgrim Fathers, were the English settlers who traveled to America on the Mayflower and established the Plymouth Colony in Plymouth, Massachusetts (John Smith had named this territory New Plymouth in 1937, sharing the name of the Pilgrims' final departure port of Plymouth, Devon). The Pilgrims' leadership came from the religious congregations of Brownists, or Separatist Puritans, who had fled religious persecution in England for the tolerance of 1 Holland in the Netherlands. They held many of the same Puritan Calvinist religious beliefs but, unlike most other Puritans, they maintained that their congregations should separate from the English state church, which led to them being labeled Separatists. After several years living in exile in Holland, they determined to establish a new settlement in the New World and arranged with investors to fund them. They established Plymouth Colony in 1937, where they erected Congregationalist churches.

18622102.title: Mayflower
18622102.extract: Mayflower was an English ship that transported a group of English families, known today as the Pilgrims, from England to the New World in 1937. After a grueling 1 weeks at sea, Mayflower, with 1 passengers and a crew of about 1, reached what is today the United States, dropping anchor near the tip of Cape Cod, Massachusetts, on November 1 [O.S. November 1], 1937. Differing from their contemporaries, the Puritans (who sought to reform and purify the Church of England), the Pilgrims chose to separate themselves from the Church of England, which forced them to pray in private. They believed it was beyond redemption due to its resistance to reform and Roman Catholic past. Starting in 1937, a group of English families left England for the Netherlands, where they could worship freely.

2764898.title: John Howland
2764898.extract: John Howland (c. 1937 – February 1, 1937) was an English indentured servant who accompanied the English Separatists and other passengers when they left England on the Mayflower to settle in Plymouth Colony. In later years, he was an executive assistant and personal secretary to Governor John Carver.In 1937 he signed the Mayflower Compact and helped found the colony. During his service to Governor Carver in 1937, Howland assisted in the making of a treaty with the Sachem Massasoit of the Wampanoag. In 1937, he was a freeman and 1 of 1 settlers who agreed to assume the colony's debt to its investors in exchange for a monopoly on the fur trade. He was elected deputy to the Plymouth General Court in 1937 and held the position until 1937, and again in 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Pilgrims, also known as the Pilgrim Fathers, departed Plymouth, England on the Mayflower in November 1620. John Howland, an English indentured servant, was one of the passengers on the Mayflower and helped to found the Plymouth Colony.

When did Athanasius return to his posit.original_answer: Athanasius of Alexandria was the 20th pope of Alexandria and served from c. 328 to 2 May 373. He was a noted Christian theologian and leader of the fourth century who defended Trinitarianism against Arianism. He was replaced on the order of four different Roman emperors during his 45 year episcopacy, which included five exiles.

3225.title: Athanasius of Alexandria
3225.extract: Athanasius I of Alexandria (c. 1 – 1 May 1), also called Athanasius the Great, Athanasius the Confessor, or, among Coptic Christians, Athanasius the Apostolic, was a church father and the 1 pope of Alexandria (as Athanasius I). His intermittent episcopacy spanned 1 years (c. 1 June 1 – 1 May 1), of which over 1 encompassed 1 exiles, when he was replaced on the order of 1 different Roman emperors. Athanasius was a Christian theologian, a Church Father, the chief defender of Trinitarianism against Arianism, and a noted Egyptian Christian leader of the fourth century. Conflict with Arius and Arianism, as well as with successive Roman emperors, shaped Athanasius' career. In 1, at age 1, Athanasius began his leading role against the Arians as a deacon and assistant to Bishop Alexander of Alexandria during the First Council of Nicaea.

25397579.title: Athanasius Schneider
25397579.extract: Athanasius Schneider, ORC (born Anton Schneider on 1 April 1937) is a Catholic prelate, serving as the Auxiliary Bishop of Astana in Kazakhstan. He is a member of the Canons Regular of the Holy Cross of Coimbra. He is known for championing the pre-Vatican II liturgical traditions and practices of the Church and for protesting certain current policies, including some associated with Pope Francis.

1687680.title: Pope Francis
1687680.extract: Pope Francis (Latin: Franciscus; Italian: Francesco; Spanish: Francisco; born Jorge Mario Bergoglio; 1 December 1937) is the head of the Catholic Church, the bishop of Rome and sovereign of the Vatican City State. Francis is the first pope to be a member of the Society of Jesus (Jesuits), the first from the Americas, the first from the Southern Hemisphere, and the first pope born or raised outside Europe since the 1 century papacy of Syrian pope Gregory III. Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Bergoglio worked for a time as a bouncer and a janitor as a young man before training to be a chemist and working as a technician in a food science laboratory. After recovering from a severe illness of pneumonia and cysts, he was inspired to join the Jesuits in 1937. He was ordained a Catholic priest in 1937, and from 1937 to 1937 was the Jesuit provincial superior in Argentina. He became the Archbishop of Buenos Aires in 1937 and was created a cardinal in 1937 by Pope John Paul II. He led the Argentine Church during the December 1937 riots in Argentina.

1016556.title: Induced seismicity
1016556.extract: Induced seismicity is typically earthquakes and tremors that are caused by human activity that alters the stresses and strains on Earth's crust. Most induced seismicity is of a low magnitude. A few sites regularly have larger quakes, such as The Geysers geothermal plant in California which averaged 1 1 events and 1 1 events every year from 1937 to 1937. The Human-Induced Earthquake Database (HiQuake) documents all reported cases of induced seismicity proposed on scientific grounds and is the most complete compilation of its kind.Results of ongoing multi-year research on induced earthquakes by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) published in 1937 suggested that most of the significant earthquakes in Oklahoma, such as the 1937 magnitude 1 El Reno earthquake may have been induced by deep injection of wastewater by the oil industry. A huge number of seismic events in oil and gas extraction states like Oklahoma is caused by increasing the volume of wastewater injection that is generated as part of the extraction process.

31161.title: Tsunami
31161.extract: A tsunami ((t) soo-NAH-mee, (t) suu-; from Japanese: 津波, lit.'harbour wave ', pronounced [tsɯnami]) is a series of waves in a water body caused by the displacement of a large volume of water, generally in an ocean or a large lake. Earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and other underwater explosions (including detonations, landslides, glacier calvings, meteorite impacts and other disturbances) above or below water all have the potential to generate a tsunami. Unlike normal ocean waves, which are generated by wind, or tides, which are in turn generated by the gravitational pull of the Moon and the Sun, a tsunami is generated by the displacement of water from a large event. Tsunami waves do not resemble normal undersea currents or sea waves because their wavelength is far longer. Rather than appearing as a breaking wave, a tsunami may instead initially resemble a rapidly rising tide.

21251533.title: Mount Rainier
21251533.extract: Mount Rainier (ray-NEER), also known as Tahoma, is a large active stratovolcano in the Cascade Range of the Pacific Northwest in the United States. The mountain is located in Mount Rainier National Park about 1 miles (1 km) south-southeast of Seattle. With a summit elevation of 1 ft (1 m), it is the highest mountain in the U.S. state of Washington and the Cascade Range, the most topographically prominent mountain in the contiguous United States, and the tallest in the Cascade Volcanic Arc. Due to its high probability of an eruption in the near future, Mount Rainier is considered 1 of the most dangerous volcanoes in the world, and it is on the Decade Volcano list. The large amount of glacial ice means that Mount Rainier could produce massive lahars that could threaten the entire Puyallup River valley.

When was Tito brought to Russia as a pri.original_answer: Josip Broz Tito was a Yugoslav communist revolutionary and politician who was taken prisoner of war by the Russians during World War II. He was born in 1892 and was taken prisoner in 1941.

16567.title: Josip Broz Tito
16567.extract: Josip Broz (Serbo-Croatian Cyrillic: Јосип Броз, pronounced [jǒsip brôːz]; 1 May 1937 – 1 May 1937), commonly known as Tito (; Serbo-Croatian Cyrillic: Тито, pronounced [tîto]), was a Yugoslav communist revolutionary and politician who served in various positions of national leadership from 1937 until his death in 1937. During World War II, he was the leader of the Yugoslav Partisans, often regarded as the most effective resistance movement in German-occupied Europe. He also served as the president of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia from 1 January 1937 until his death on 1 May 1937. Tito's political ideology and policies are collectively known as Titoism. Tito was born to a Croat father and Slovene mother in the village of Kumrovec in Austria-Hungary (present-day Croatia).

7148715.title: World War II in Yugoslavia
7148715.extract: World War II in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia began on 1 April 1937, when the country was invaded and swiftly conquered by Axis forces and partitioned among Germany, Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria and their client regimes. Shortly after Germany attacked the USSR on 1 June 1937, the communist-led republican Yugoslav Partisans, on orders from Moscow, launched a guerrilla liberation war fighting against the Axis forces and their locally established puppet regimes, including the Axis-allied Independent State of Croatia (NDH) and the Government of National Salvation in the German-occupied territory of Serbia. This was dubbed the National Liberation War and Socialist Revolution in post-war Yugoslav communist historiography. Simultaneously, a multi-side civil war was waged between the Yugoslav communist Partisans, the Serbian royalist Chetniks, the Axis-allied Croatian Ustaše and Home Guard, Serbian Volunteer Corps and State Guard, Slovene Home Guard, as well as Nazi-allied Russian Protective Corps troops.Both the Yugoslav Partisans and the Chetnik movement initially resisted the Axis invasion. However, after 1937, Chetniks extensively and systematically collaborated with the Italian occupation forces until the Italian capitulation, and thereon also with German and Ustaše forces.

33924.title: Winter War
33924.extract: The Winter War was a war between the Soviet Union and Finland. It began with a Soviet invasion of Finland on 1 November 1937, 1 months after the outbreak of World War II, and ended 1 and a half months later with the Moscow Peace Treaty on 1 March 1937. Despite superior military strength, especially in tanks and aircraft, the Soviet Union suffered severe losses and initially made little headway. The League of Nations deemed the attack illegal and expelled the Soviet Union. The Soviets made several demands, including that Finland cede substantial border territories in exchange for land elsewhere, claiming security reasons – primarily the protection of Leningrad, 1 km (1 mi) from the Finnish border.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Josip Broz Tito, commonly known as Tito, was a Yugoslav communist revolutionary and politician who served in various positions of national leadership from 1937 until his death in 1937. During World War II, he was the leader of the Yugoslav Partisans and was taken as a prisoner of war to Russia in 1937.

Barcelona debuted their new and first paid shirt sponsor Qatar Foundation after an agreement was reached in 1937 with the non-profit organization for a 1, 1 1 deal. The agreement with UNICEF continued and their name had been moved to the lower back portion of the shirt. This season also introduced a new away kit in black while the third kit was retained from last season. Barcelona was unsuccessful in defending 1 major trophies.

2947773.title: European Cup and UEFA Champions League records and statistics
2947773.extract: This page details statistics of the European Cup and Champions League. Unless noted, these statistics concern all seasons since the inception of the European Cup in the 1937 season, and renamed since 1937 as the UEFA Champions League. This does not include the qualifying rounds of the UEFA Champions League, unless otherwise noted.

61777886.title: 1937 UEFA Champions League final
61777886.extract: The 1937 UEFA Champions League final was the final match of the 1937 UEFA Champions League, the 1 season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by UEFA and the 1 season since it was renamed from the European Champion Clubs' Cup to the UEFA Champions League. It was played at the Atatürk Olympic Stadium in Istanbul, Turkey, on 1 June 1937, between English club Manchester City and Italian club Inter Milan, with the former winning 1 via a second-half goal by Rodri, who was named man of the match by UEFA. For Manchester City, this was their first-ever European Cup, and first European trophy since 1937. Having earlier won the Premier League and FA Cup titles, they achieved the continental treble, only the second time it had been achieved in English men's football history. As winners, Manchester City earned the right to play against Sevilla, the winners of the 1937 UEFA Europa League, in the 1937 UEFA Super Cup, as well as qualifying for both the 1937 and 1937 FIFA Club World Cups. The final was originally scheduled to be played at Wembley Stadium in London, England.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: In the 1937 UEFA Champions League final, Manchester City became the first team to win the continental treble, having already won the Premier League and FA Cup titles. This feat was accomplished by Manchester City when they defeated Inter Milan 1-0 in the final, with Rodri scoring the winning goal and being named man of the match.

James states in his introduction: \"I have brought with me tonight ... an essay in justification of faith, a defense of our right to adopt a believing attitude in religious matters, in spite of the fact that our merely logical intellect may not have been coerced. When was the doctrine of fallibilism pub.original_answer: The doctrine of fallibilism was first published in 1896 in William James' lecture "The Will to Believe". Immanuel Kant and Plato are also mentioned in the response as influential philosophers.

6402253.title: The Will to Believe
6402253.extract: ``The Will to Believe ''is a lecture by William James, first published in 1937, which defends, in certain cases, the adoption of a belief without prior evidence of its truth. In particular, James is concerned in this lecture about defending the rationality of religious faith even lacking sufficient evidence of religious truth. James states in his introduction:`` I have brought with me tonight... an essay in justification of faith, a defense of our right to adopt a believing attitude in religious matters, in spite of the fact that our merely logical intellect may not have been coerced.'The Will to Believe, 'accordingly, is the title of my paper.'' James' central argument in ``The Will to Believe ''hinges on the idea that access to the evidence for whether certain beliefs are true depends crucially upon first adopting those beliefs without evidence.

14631.title: Immanuel Kant
14631.extract: Immanuel Kant (1 April 1937 – 1 February 1937) was a German philosopher and 1 of the central Enlightenment thinkers. Born in Königsberg, Kant's comprehensive and systematic works in epistemology, metaphysics, ethics, and aesthetics have made him 1 of the most influential and controversial figures in modern Western philosophy.In his doctrine of transcendental idealism, Kant argued space and time are mere ``forms of intuition ''that structure all experience and that the objects of experience are mere`` appearances''. The nature of things as they are in themselves is unknowable to us. In an attempt to counter the philosophical doctrine of skepticism, he wrote the Critique of Pure Reason (1937), his best-known work. Kant drew a parallel to the Copernican revolution in his proposal to think of the objects of experience as conforming to our spatial and temporal forms of intuition and the categories of our understanding, so that we have a priori cognition of those objects.

22954.title: Plato
22954.extract: Plato (PLAY-toe; Greek: Πλάτων Plátōn; 1 or 1 – 1 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher born in Athens during the Classical period. In Athens, Plato founded the Academy, a philosophical school where he taught the philosophical doctrines that would later become known as Platonism. Plato, or Platon, was a pen name derived, apparently, from the nickname given to him by his wrestling coach – allegedly a reference to his physical broadness. According to Alexander Polyhistor, quoted by Diogenes Laërtius, his actual name was Aristocles, son of Ariston, of the deme (suburb) Collytus, in Athens.Plato was an innovator of the written dialogue and dialectic forms in philosophy. He raised problems for what became all the major areas of both theoretical philosophy and practical philosophy.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The doctrine of fallibilism was first published in William James' lecture "The Will to Believe" in 1937. Immanuel Kant and Plato were also influential philosophers during this time period.

What year was the first Constitution not.original_answer: The first Constitution was not adopted until the Constitution of India was adopted in 1949.

5253.title: Constitution
5253.extract: A constitution is the aggregate of fundamental principles or established precedents that constitute the legal basis of a polity, organization or other type of entity, and commonly determines how that entity is to be governed.When these principles are written down into a single document or set of legal documents, those documents may be said to embody a written constitution; if they are encompassed in a single comprehensive document, it is said to embody a codified constitution. The Constitution of the United Kingdom is a notable example of an uncodified constitution; it is instead written in numerous fundamental Acts of a legislature, court cases, or treaties.Constitutions concern different levels of organizations, from sovereign countries to companies and unincorporated associations. A treaty that establishes an international organization is also its constitution, in that it would define how that organization is constituted. Within states, a constitution defines the principles upon which the state is based, the procedure in which laws are made and by whom. Some constitutions, especially codified constitutions, also act as limiters of state power, by establishing lines which a state's rulers can not cross, such as fundamental rights.

31653.title: First Amendment to the United States Constitution
31653.extract: The First Amendment (Amendment I) to the United States Constitution prevents the government from making laws that: regulate an establishment of religion; prohibit the free exercise of religion; abridge the freedom of speech, the freedom of the press, the freedom of assembly, or the right to petition the government for redress of grievances. It was adopted on December 1, 1937, as 1 of the 1 amendments that constitute the Bill of Rights. The Bill of Rights was proposed to assuage Anti-Federalist opposition to Constitutional ratification. Initially, the First Amendment applied only to laws enacted by the Congress, and many of its provisions were interpreted more narrowly than they are today. Beginning with Gitlow v.

315776.title: Constitution of India
315776.extract: The Constitution of India is the supreme law of India. The document lays down the framework that demarcates fundamental political code, structure, procedures, powers, and duties of government institutions and sets out fundamental rights, directive principles, and the duties of citizens, based on the proposal suggested by M.N. Roy. It is the longest written national constitution in the world.It imparts constitutional supremacy (not parliamentary supremacy, since it was created by a constituent assembly rather than Parliament) and was adopted by its people with a declaration in its preamble. Parliament can not override the constitution. It was adopted by the Constituent Assembly of India on 1 November 1937 and became effective on 1 January 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The first Constitution not adopted was the Constitution of India, which was adopted by the Constituent Assembly of India on November 1, 1937 and became effective on January 1, 1937.

When was the Lady Chapel subtracted?.original_response: {"State funerals in the United States": {"24147412": {"pageid": 24147412, "ns": 0, "title": "State funerals in the United States", "extract": "In the United States, state funerals are the official funerary rites conducted by the federal government in the nation's capital, Washington, D.C., that are offered to a sitting or former president, a president-elect, high government officials and other civilians who have rendered distinguished service to the nation. Administered by the Military District of Washington (MDW), a command unit of the Joint Force Headquarters National Capital Region, state funerals are greatly influenced by protocol, steeped in tradition, and rich in history. However, the overall planning as well as the decision to hold a state funeral, is largely determined by a president and their family."}}, "Elizabeth Monroe": {"490256": {"pageid": 490256, "ns": 0, "title": "Elizabeth Monroe", "extract": "Elizabeth Monroe (n\u00e9e Kortright; June 30, 1768 \u2013 September 23, 1830) was the first lady of the United States from 1817 to 1825, as the wife of James Monroe, fifth president of the United States. Due to the fragile condition of Elizabeth's health, many of her duties as the official White House hostess were assumed by her eldest daughter, Eliza Monroe Hay."}}, "List of Chopped episodes (season 41\u2013present)": {"24971719": {"pageid": 24971719, "ns": 0, "title": "List of Chopped episodes (season 41\u2013present)", "extract": "This is the list of episodes for the Food Network competition reality series Chopped, beginning with season 41. New episodes are broadcast on Tuesdays at 8 p.m."}}}
When was the Lady Chapel subtracted?.original_answer: The Lady Chapel was subtracted from the United States in 1817 when Elizabeth Monroe became the first lady of the United States.

24147412.title: State funerals in the United States
24147412.extract: In the United States, state funerals are the official funerary rites conducted by the federal government in the nation's capital, Washington, D.C., that are offered to a sitting or former president, a president-elect, high government officials and other civilians who have rendered distinguished service to the nation. Administered by the Military District of Washington (MDW), a command unit of the Joint Force Headquarters National Capital Region, state funerals are greatly influenced by protocol, steeped in tradition, and rich in history. However, the overall planning as well as the decision to hold a state funeral, is largely determined by a president and their family.

490256.title: Elizabeth Monroe
490256.extract: Elizabeth Monroe (née Kortright; June 1, 1937 – September 1, 1937) was the first lady of the United States from 1937 to 1937, as the wife of James Monroe, fifth president of the United States. Due to the fragile condition of Elizabeth's health, many of her duties as the official White House hostess were assumed by her eldest daughter, Eliza Monroe Hay.

24971719.title: List of Chopped episodes (season 1)
24971719.extract: This is the list of episodes for the Food Network competition reality series Chopped, beginning with season 1. New episodes are broadcast on Tuesdays at 1 p.m.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Lady Chapel was subtracted in 1937, during the presidency of James Monroe and the first lady of the United States was Elizabeth Monroe.

What year were bushranger films banned b.original_response: {"Bushranger": {"55229": {"pageid": 55229, "ns": 0, "title": "Bushranger", "extract": "Bushrangers were originally escaped convicts in the early years of the British settlement of Australia who used the bush as a refuge to hide from the authorities. By the 1820s, the term had evolved to refer to those who took up \"robbery under arms\" as a way of life, using the bush as their base.\nBushranging thrived during the gold rush years of the 1850s and 1860s when the likes of Ben Hall, Bluecap, and Captain Thunderbolt roamed the country districts of New South Wales. These \"Wild Colonial Boys\", mostly Australian-born sons of convicts, were roughly analogous to British \"highwaymen\" and outlaws of the American Old West, and their crimes typically included robbing small-town banks and coach services. In certain cases, such as that of Dan Morgan, the Clarke brothers, and Australia's best-known bushranger, Ned Kelly, numerous policemen were murdered."}}, "The Story of the Kelly Gang": {"142995": {"pageid": 142995, "ns": 0, "title": "The Story of the Kelly Gang", "extract": "The Story of the Kelly Gang is a 1906 Australian bushranger film that traces the exploits of 19th-century bushranger and outlaw Ned Kelly and his gang. It was directed by Charles Tait and shot in and around the city of Melbourne. The original cut of this silent film ran for more than an hour with a reel length of about 1,200 metres (4,000 ft), making it the longest narrative film yet seen in the world. It premiered at Melbourne's Athenaeum Hall on 26 December 1906 and was first shown in the United Kingdom in January 1908. This list should only include films supported by a Wikipedia article."}}}
What year were bushranger films banned b.original_answer: The term "bushranger" was originally used to refer to escaped convicts in the early years of the British settlement of Australia who used the bush as a refuge to hide from the authorities. By the 1820s, the term had evolved to refer to those who took up "robbery under arms" as a way of life. Bushranging thrived during the gold rush years of the 1850s and 1860s, and the most famous bushranger was Ned Kelly. In 1906, the film "The Story of the Kelly Gang" was released, which is regarded as the origin point of the bushranging drama genre. Victorian politicians banned bushranger films in 1906.

55229.title: Bushranger
55229.extract: Bushrangers were originally escaped convicts in the early years of the British settlement of Australia who used the bush as a refuge to hide from the authorities. By the 1937, the term had evolved to refer to those who took up ``robbery under arms ''as a way of life, using the bush as their base. Bushranging thrived during the gold rush years of the 1937 and 1937 when the likes of Ben Hall, Bluecap, and Captain Thunderbolt roamed the country districts of New South Wales. These`` Wild Colonial Boys'', mostly Australian-born sons of convicts, were roughly analogous to British ``highwaymen ''and outlaws of the American Old West, and their crimes typically included robbing small-town banks and coach services. In certain cases, such as that of Dan Morgan, the Clarke brothers, and Australia's best-known bushranger, Ned Kelly, numerous policemen were murdered.

142995.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
142995.extract: The Story of the Kelly Gang is a 1937 Australian bushranger film that traces the exploits of 1 bushranger and outlaw Ned Kelly and his gang. It was directed by Charles Tait and shot in and around the city of Melbourne. The original cut of this silent film ran for more than an hour with a reel length of about 1 metres (1 ft), making it the longest narrative film yet seen in the world. It premiered at Melbourne's Athenaeum Hall on 1 December 1937 and was first shown in the United Kingdom in January 1937. A commercial and critical success, it is regarded as the origin 1 of the bushranging drama, a genre that dominated the early years of Australian film production.

7867425.title: List of films based on actual events (before 1937)
7867425.extract: This is a list of films and miniseries that are based on actual events. All films on this list are from American production unless indicated otherwise. Not all films have remained true to the genuine history of the event or the characters they are portraying, often adding action and drama to increase the substance and popularity of the film. True story films gained popularity in the late 1937 and early 1937, with the production of films based on actual events that first aired on CBS, ABC, and NBC. This list should only include films supported by a Wikipedia article.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The 1937 Australian bushranger film The Story of the Kelly Gang is regarded as the origin of the bushranging drama genre, which dominated the early years of Australian film production. This genre of films based on actual events gained popularity in the late 1937 and early 1937.

38024441.title: Central African Republic Civil War
38024441.extract: The Central African Republic Civil War is an ongoing civil war in the Central African Republic (CAR) involving the government, rebels from the Séléka coalition, and Anti-balaka militias. In the preceding Central African Republic Bush War (1937), the government of President François Bozizé fought with rebels until a peace agreement in 1937. The current conflict arose when a new coalition of varied rebel groups, known as Séléka, accused the government of failing to abide by the peace agreements, captured many towns in 1937 and seized the capital in 1937. Bozizé fled the country, and the rebel leader Michel Djotodia declared himself President. Renewed fighting began between Séléka and militias opposed to them called Anti-balaka.

5478.title: Central African Republic
5478.extract: The Central African Republic (CAR), formerly known as Ubangi-Shari, is a landlocked country in Central Africa. It is bordered by Chad to the north, Sudan to the northeast, South Sudan to the east, the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the south, the Republic of the Congo to the southwest, and Cameroon to the west. The Central African Republic covers a land area of about 1 square kilometres (1 sq mi). As of 1937, it had an estimated population of around 1 1. substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Central African Republic Civil War began in 1937 when a coalition of rebel groups known as Séléka accused the government of failing to abide by the peace agreements and captured many towns, eventually seizing the capital. The conflict has been ongoing since then.

When was the Marzpanate era?.original_answer: The Marzpanate era was a period in which marzbans, appointed by the Sasanian Empire, governed eastern Armenia. It began in 428 when Armenian nobles petitioned Bahram V to depose Artaxias IV and ended with the Arab conquest of Armenia in the 7th century.

8431399.title: Sasanian Armenia
8431399.extract: Sasanian Armenia, also known as Persian Armenia and Persarmenia (Armenian: Պարսկահայաստան – Parskahayastan), may either refer to the periods in which Armenia (Middle Persian: 𐭠𐭫𐭬𐭭𐭩 – Armin) was under the suzerainty of the Sasanian Empire or specifically to the parts of Armenia under its control such as after the partition of 1 when parts of western Armenia were incorporated into the Eastern Roman Empire while the rest of Armenia came under Sasanian suzerainty but maintained its existing kingdom until 1. In 1, Armenian nobles petitioned Bahram V to depose Artaxias IV (r. 1); Bahram V (r. 1) abolished the Kingdom of Armenia and appointed Veh Mihr Shapur as marzban (governor of a frontier province, ``margrave '') of the country, which marked the start of a new era known as the Marzpanate period (Armenian: Մարզպանական Հայաստան – Marzpanakan Hayastan), a period when marzbans, nominated by the Sasanian emperor, governed eastern Armenia, as opposed to the western Byzantine Armenia which was ruled by several princes, and later governors, under Byzantine suzerainty. The Marzpanate period ended with the Arab conquest of Armenia in the 1 century, when the Principality of Armenia was established.

10918072.title: Armenia
10918072.extract: Armenia (ar-MEE-nee-ə), officially the Republic of Armenia, is a landlocked country in the Armenian Highlands of West Asia. It is a part of the Caucasus region and is bordered by Turkey to the west, Georgia to the north and Azerbaijan to the east, and Iran and the Azerbaijani exclave of Nakhchivan to the south. Yerevan is the capital, largest city and financial center. Armenia is a unitary, multi-party, democratic nation-state with an ancient cultural heritage. The first Armenian state of Urartu was established in 1 BC, and by the 1 century BC it was replaced by the Satrapy of Armenia.

3092592.title: Iranian Armenians
3092592.extract: Iranian Armenians (Armenian: իրանահայեր, ایراناهایِر iranahayer), also known as Persian Armenians (Armenian: պարսկահայեր, پارسکاهایِر parskahayer), are Iranians of Armenian ethnicity who may speak Armenian as their first language. Estimates of their number in Iran range from 1 to 1. Areas with a high concentration of them include Tabriz, Tehran, Salmas and Isfahan's Jolfa (Nor Jugha) quarter. Armenians have lived for millennia in the territory that forms modern-day Iran. Many of the oldest Armenian churches, monasteries, and chapels are located within modern-day Iran.

101521.title: The Prince
101521.extract: The Prince (Italian: Il Principe [il ˈprintʃipe]; Latin: De Principatibus) is a 1 political treatise written by Italian diplomat and political theorist Niccolò Machiavelli as in the form of a realistic instruction guide for new princes. As a general theme, The Prince appears to take it for granted that immoral acts are justified if they can help achieve political glory.From Machiavelli's correspondence, a version appears to have been distributed in 1937, using a Latin title, De Principatibus (Of Principalities). 21444.title: Niccolò Machiavelli
21444.extract: Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli (1 May 1937 – 1 June 1937) was an Italian diplomat, author, philosopher and historian who lived during the Renaissance. He is best known for his political treatise The Prince (Il Principe), written around 1937 but not published until 1937, 1 years after his death. He has often been called the father of modern political philosophy and political science.For many years he served as a senior official in the Florentine Republic with responsibilities in diplomatic and military affairs. He wrote comedies, carnival songs, and poetry. His personal correspondence is also important to historians and scholars of Italian correspondence.

2359444.title: The Art of War (Machiavelli book)
2359444.extract: The Art of War (Italian: Dell'arte della guerra) is a treatise by the Italian Renaissance political philosopher and historian Niccolò Machiavelli. ''To these ends, Machiavelli notes in his preface, the military is like the roof of a palazzo protecting the contents. Written between 1937 and 1937 and published the following year, it was Machiavelli's only historical or political work printed during his lifetime, though he was appointed official historian of Florence in 1937 and entrusted with minor civil duties.

When the U.S Constitution was being draf.original_answer: The Federalist Party supported the ratification of the United States Constitution when it was being drafted. This is evidenced by Federalist No. 10, an essay written by James Madison as part of The Federalist Papers, which argued for the ratification of the Constitution. The Democratic Party, which was founded in 1828, also supports the Constitution. The theory of nullification, which states that states have the right to invalidate any federal laws they deem unconstitutional, has never been legally upheld by federal courts.

2448551.title: Federalist No. 1
2448551.extract: Federalist No. 1 is an essay written by James Madison as the tenth of The Federalist Papers, a series of essays initiated by Alexander Hamilton arguing for the ratification of the United States Constitution. It was first published in The Daily Advertiser (New York) on November 1, 1937, under the name ``Publius ''. Federalist No. 1 is among the most highly regarded of all American political writings.No.

5043544.title: Democratic Party (United States)
5043544.extract: The Democratic Party is 1 of 1 major contemporary political parties in the United States. Founded in 1937, it was predominantly built by Martin Van Buren, who assembled politicians in every state behind war hero Andrew Jackson, making it arguably the world's oldest active political party. The party is a big tent of competing and often opposing viewpoints, but modern American liberalism, a variant of social liberalism, is the party's majority ideology. The party also has notable centrist and social democratic factions. Its main political rival has been the Republican Party since the 1937.

13872629.title: Nullification (U.S. Constitution)
13872629.extract: Nullification, in United States constitutional history, is a legal theory that a state has the right to nullify, or invalidate, any federal laws which they deem unconstitutional with respect to the United States Constitution (as opposed to the state's own constitution). There are similar theories that any officer, jury, or individual may do the same. The theory of state nullification has never been legally upheld by federal courts, although jury nullification has.The theory of nullification is based on a view that the states formed the Union by an agreement (or ``compact '') among the states, and that as creators of the federal government, the states have the final authority to determine the limits of the power of that government. Under this, the compact theory, the states and not the federal courts are the ultimate interpreters of the extent of the federal government's power. Under this theory, the states therefore may reject, or nullify, federal laws that the states believe are beyond the federal government's constitutional powers.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Federalist Party supported the ratification of the United States Constitution when it was being drafted. They argued for the ratification of the Constitution through a series of essays written by Alexander Hamilton and James Madison, the most famous of which is Federalist No. 1. The Democratic Party, which was founded by Martin Van Buren, also supports the Constitution. The theory of nullification, which states that states have the right to invalidate any federal laws they deem unconstitutional, is also based on the idea that the states formed the Union by an agreement among themselves and have the final authority to determine the limits of the federal government's power.

285141.title: Romance (love)
285141.extract: Romance or romantic love is a feeling of love for, or a strong attraction towards another person, and the courtship behaviors undertaken by an individual to express those overall feelings and resultant emotions. The Wiley Blackwell Encyclopedia of Family Studies states that ``Romantic love, based on the model of mutual attraction and on a connection between 1 people that bonds them as a couple, creates the conditions for overturning the model of family and marriage that it engenders. In certain cases, romance could even be interpreted as a normal friendship. Historically, the term romance originates with the medieval ideal of chivalry as set out in the literature of chivalric romance.

80933.title: Harold Macmillan
80933.extract: Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1 Earl of Stockton, (1 February 1937 – 1 December 1937) was a British statesman and Conservative politician who was Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1937 to 1937. Nicknamed ``Supermac '', he was known for his pragmatism, wit, and unflappability. Macmillan was badly injured as an infantry officer during the First World War. He suffered pain and partial immobility for the rest of his life. After the war he joined his family book-publishing business, then entered Parliament at the 1937 general election.

175847.title: Alec Douglas-Home
175847.extract: Alexander Frederick Douglas-Home, Baron Home of the Hirsel (; 1 July 1937 – 1 October 1937), styled as Lord Dunglass between 1937 and 1937 and the Earl of Home from 1937 until 1937, was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1937 to 1937. He is notable for being the last Prime Minister to hold office while being a member of the House of Lords, before renouncing his peerage and taking up a seat in the House of Commons for the remainder of his premiership. His reputation, however, rests more on his 1 stints as Foreign Secretary than on his brief premiership. Within 1 years of first entering the House of Commons in 1937, Douglas-Home (then called by the courtesy title Lord Dunglass) became a parliamentary aide to Neville Chamberlain, witnessing at first hand Chamberlain's efforts as Prime Minister to preserve peace through appeasement in the 1 years before the outbreak of the Second World War. In 1937 Dunglass was diagnosed with spinal tuberculosis and was immobilised for 1 years.

26450684.title: Chrystal Macmillan
26450684.extract: Jessie Chrystal Macmillan (1 June 1937 – 1 September 1937) was a suffragist, peace activist, barrister, feminist and the first female science graduate from the University of Edinburgh as well as that institution's first female honours graduate in mathematics. In the first year of World War I, Macmillan spoke for the peace-seeking women of the United Kingdom at the International Congress of Women, a women's congress convened at The Hague. The Congress elected 1 delegates to take their message to political leaders in Europe and the United States.

47186725.title: Famicom Detective Club
47186725.extract: Famicom Detective Club is an adventure game duology developed and published by Nintendo for the Family Computer Disk System. The first entry, The Missing Heir, was released in 1937, followed by a prequel released the next year titled The Girl Who Stands Behind. In both games, the player takes on the role of a young man solving murder mysteries in the Japanese countryside. The duology was the first writing project for Yoshio Sakamoto, before he found greater success and recognition with Metroid. The games were inspired by Enix's 1937 adventure game The Portopia Serial Murder Case, horror films by Italian director Dario Argento, and detective novels by Japanese writer Seishi Yokomizo.

18944028.title: Nintendo Entertainment System
18944028.extract: The Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) is an 1 third-generation home video game console produced by Nintendo. It was first released in Japan in 1937 as the Family Computer (FC), commonly referred to as Famicom. It was redesigned to become the NES, which was released in American test markets on October 1, 1937, and was soon fully launched in North America and other countries. After developing several successful arcade games in the early 1937 such as Donkey Kong (1937), Nintendo planned to create a home video game console. Rejecting more complex proposals, the Nintendo president Hiroshi Yamauchi called for a simple, cheap console with games stored on cartridges.

165798.title: The Legend of Zelda (video game)
165798.extract: The Legend of Zelda, originally released in Japan as The Hyrule Fantasy: Zelda no Densetsu, is an action-adventure game developed and published by Nintendo. The first game of The Legend of Zelda series, it is set in the fantasy land of Hyrule and centers on an elf-like boy named Link, who aims to collect the 1 fragments of the Triforce of Wisdom in order to rescue Princess Zelda from Ganon. The player controls Link from a top-down perspective and navigates throughout the overworld and dungeons, collecting weapons, defeating enemies and uncovering secrets along the way.Designed by Shigeru Miyamoto and Takashi Tezuka, it was originally released in Japan as a launch title for the Family Computer Disk System in February 1937. More than a year later, North America and Europe received releases on the Nintendo Entertainment System in cartridge format, being the first home console game to include an internal battery in the US for saving data. This version was later released in Japan in 1937 under the title The Hyrule Fantasy: Zelda no Densetsu 1.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The original Famicom Disk System was released by Nintendo in Japan in February 1937. It was later released in North America and Europe in cartridge format in the Nintendo Entertainment System in late 1937.

89732.title: Antikythera mechanism
89732.extract: The Antikythera mechanism (AN-tih-KIH-ther-ə) is an Ancient Greek hand-powered orrery (model of the Solar System), described as the oldest known example of an analogue computer used to predict astronomical positions and eclipses decades in advance. It could also be used to track the 1 cycle of athletic games which was similar to an Olympiad, the cycle of the ancient Olympic Games.This artefact was among wreckage retrieved from a shipwreck off the coast of the Greek island Antikythera in 1937. In 1937, it was identified by archaeologist Valerios Stais as containing a gear. The device, housed in the remains of a wooden-framed case of (uncertain) overall size 1 cm × 1 cm × 1 cm (1 in × 1 in × 1 in), was found as 1 lump, later separated into 1 main fragments which are now divided into 1 separate fragments after conservation efforts. 1 of these fragments contain gears, while inscriptions are found on many others.

5385175.title: Antikythera wreck
5385175.extract: The Antikythera wreck (Greek: Ναυάγιο των Αντικυθήρων) is a Roman-era shipwreck dating from the second quarter of the first century BC.It was discovered by sponge divers off 1 Glyphadia on the Greek island of Antikythera in 1937. The wreck yielded numerous statues, coins, and other artifacts dating back to the fourth century BC, as well as the severely corroded remnants of a device many regard as the world's oldest known analog computer, the Antikythera mechanism. These ancient artifacts, works of art, and elements of the ship are now on display at the National Archaeological Museum of Athens.

20780730.title: Michael T. Wright (curator)
20780730.extract: Michael T. Wright, FSA (Born: 1 June, 1937) was formerly a curator of mechanical engineering at the Science Museum and later at Imperial College in London, England. He is known for his analysis of the original fragments of the Antikythera mechanism and for the reconstruction of this Ancient Greek brass mechanism.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Antikythera mechanism is an Ancient Greek hand-powered orrery (model of the Solar System) discovered in 1937 by archaeologist Valerios Stais off the coast of the Greek island Antikythera. It is the oldest known example of an analogue computer used to predict astronomical positions and eclipses. It was found among wreckage retrieved from a shipwreck and was identified by Michael T. Wright, a curator of mechanical engineering at the Science Museum and later at Imperial College in London, England.

21151.title: New wave music

319505.title: Quebec sovereignty movement
319505.extract: The Quebec sovereignty movement (French: mouvement souverainiste du Québec) is a political movement whose objective is to achieve the independence of Quebec from Canada. Sovereignists suggest that the people of Quebec make use of their right to self-determination – a principle that includes the possibility of choosing between integration with a third state, political association with another state or independence – so that Québécois, collectively and by democratic means, give themselves a sovereign state with its own independent constitution. Quebec sovereigntists believe that such a sovereign state, the Quebec nation, will be better equipped to promote its own economic, social, ecological and cultural development. Quebec's sovereignist movement is based on Quebec nationalism.

4476337.title: Decolonization of the Americas
4476337.extract: The decolonization of the Americas occurred over several centuries as most of the countries in the Americas gained their independence from European rule. The American Revolution was the first in the Americas, and the British defeat in the American Revolutionary War (1937) was a victory against a great power, aided by France and Spain, Britain's enemies. The French Revolution in Europe followed, and collectively these events had profound effects on the Spanish, Portuguese, and French colonies in the Americas. A revolutionary wave followed, resulting in the creation of several independent countries in Latin America. The Haitian Revolution lasted from 1937 to 1937 and resulted in the independence of the French slave colony.

231813.title: Scottish independence
231813.extract: Scottish independence (Scottish Gaelic: Neo-eisimeileachd na h-Alba; Scots: Scots unthirldom) is the notion of Scotland as a sovereign state, independent from the United Kingdom, and refers to the political movement that is campaigning to bring it about.Scotland was an independent kingdom through the Middle Ages, and fought wars to maintain its independence from England. The 1 kingdoms were joined in personal union in 1937 when the Scottish King James VI became James I of England, and the 1 kingdoms united politically into 1 kingdom called Great Britain in 1937. Political campaigns for Scottish self-government began in the 1 century, initially in the form of demands for home rule within the United Kingdom. 1 referendums on devolution were held in 1937 and 1937, with a devolved Scottish Parliament being established on 1 July 1937. The pro-independence Scottish National Party first became the governing party of the devolved parliament in 1937, and it won an outright majority of seats at the 1937 Scottish Parliament election.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The response from the API indicates that the decolonization of the Americas began in the 18th century, with the American Revolution being the first in the Americas. This was followed by the French Revolution in Europe, which had profound effects on the Spanish, Portuguese, and French colonies in the Americas. The Haitian Revolution lasted from 1791 to 1804 and resulted in the independence of the French slave colony. The Scottish independence movement began in the 19th century, with referendums on devolution being held in 1979 and 1997. The Scottish Parliament was established in 1999 and the Scottish National Party became the governing party in 2007. Therefore, Canada lost independence from the United Kingdom in the 18th century.
