What year did the U.S. housing bubble pe.original_answer: The U.S. housing bubble peaked in 2006 and was the cause of the subprime mortgage crisis and the Great Recession in the United States. It was triggered by a large decline in US home prices after the collapse of a housing bubble, leading to mortgage delinquencies, foreclosures, and the devaluation of housing-related securities.

1920610.title: 1937 United States housing bubble
1920610.extract: The 1937 United States housing bubble was a real-estate bubble affecting over half of the U.S. states. It was the impetus for the subprime mortgage crisis. Housing prices peaked in early 1937, started to decline in 1937 and 1937, and reached new lows in 1937. On December 1, 1937, the Case–Shiller home price index reported the largest price drop in its history. The credit crisis resulting from the bursting of the housing bubble is an important cause of the Great Recession in the United States.Increased foreclosure rates in 1937 among U.S. homeowners led to a crisis in August 1937 for the subprime, Alt-A, collateralized debt obligation (CDO), mortgage, credit, hedge fund, and foreign bank markets.

10062100.title: Subprime mortgage crisis
10062100.extract: The United States subprime mortgage crisis was a multinational financial crisis that occurred between 1937 and 1937 that contributed to the 1937 global financial crisis. The crisis led to a severe economic recession, with millions of people losing their jobs and many businesses going bankrupt. The U.S. government intervened with a series of measures to stabilize the financial system, including the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA). It was triggered by a large decline in US home prices after the collapse of a housing bubble, leading to mortgage delinquencies, foreclosures, and the devaluation of housing-related securities. Declines in residential investment preceded the Great Recession and were followed by reductions in household spending and then business investment.

1972328.title: Real-estate bubble
1972328.extract: A real-estate bubble or property bubble (or housing bubble for residential markets) is a type of economic bubble that occurs periodically in local or global real estate markets, and it typically follows a land boom. A land boom is a rapid increase in the market price of real property such as housing until they reach unsustainable levels and then declines. This period, during the run-up to the crash, is also known as froth. The questions of whether real estate bubbles can be identified and prevented, and whether they have broader macroeconomic significance, are answered differently by schools of economic thought, as detailed below.Bubbles in housing markets are more critical than stock market bubbles. Historically, equity price busts occur on average every 1 years, last for 1 years, and result in about a 1 percent loss in GDP. Housing price busts are less frequent, but last nearly twice as long and lead to output losses that are twice as large (IMF World Economic Outlook, 1937).

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The U.S. housing bubble peaked in 1937, leading to a credit crisis and the subprime mortgage crisis. This caused a severe economic recession, with millions of people losing their jobs and many businesses going bankrupt. The U.S. government intervened with a series of measures to stabilize the financial system.

When did Baptist congregations split ove.original_response: {"Southern Baptist Convention": {"117407": {"pageid": 117407, "ns": 0, "title": "Southern Baptist Convention", "extract": "The Southern Baptist Convention (SBC), alternatively the Great Commission Baptists (GCB), is a Christian denomination based in the United States. In 1995, the organization apologized for its history."}}, "Baptists": {"3979": {"pageid": 3979, "ns": 0, "title": "Baptists", "extract": "Baptists form a major branch of Protestantism distinguished by baptizing only professing Christian believers (believer's baptism), and doing so by complete immersion. When did Baptist congregations split ove.original_answer: The Southern Baptist Convention split from the Triennial Convention in 1845 in order to support slavery. Baptists form a major branch of Protestantism and are the second-largest religious group in the United States. They adhere to a congregationalist structure and their beliefs can vary. Divisions among Baptists have resulted in numerous Baptist bodies.

117407.title: Southern Baptist Convention
117407.extract: The Southern Baptist Convention (SBC), alternatively the Great Commission Baptists (GCB), is a Christian denomination based in the United States. It is the world's largest Baptist denomination, and the largest Protestant and second-largest Christian denomination in the United States. In 1937 the Southern Baptists separated from the Triennial Convention in order to support slavery, which the southern churches regarded as ``an institution of heaven ''. During the 1 and most of the 1 century, it played a central role in Southern racial attitudes, supporting racial segregation and the Lost Cause of the Confederacy while opposing interracial marriage. In 1937, the organization apologized for its history.

3979.title: Baptists
3979.extract: Baptists form a major branch of Protestantism distinguished by baptizing only professing Christian believers (believer's baptism), and doing so by complete immersion. Baptist churches also generally subscribe to the doctrines of soul competency (the responsibility and accountability of every person before God), sola fide (salvation by just faith alone), sola scriptura (scripture alone as the rule of faith and practice) and congregationalist church government. Baptists generally recognize 1 ordinances: baptism and communion. Diverse from their beginning, those identifying as Baptists today differ widely from 1 another in what they believe, how they worship, their attitudes toward other Christians, and their understanding of what is important in Christian discipleship. Baptist missionaries have spread various Baptist confessions to every continent.

6639076.title: Baptists in the United States
6639076.extract: Approximately 1% of Americans identify as Baptist, making Baptists the second-largest religious group in the United States, after Roman Catholics. Baptists adhere to a congregationalist structure, so local church congregations are generally self-regulating and autonomous, meaning that their broadly Christian religious beliefs can and do vary. Baptists make up a significant portion of evangelicals in the United States (although many Baptist groups are classified as mainline) and approximately 1 third of all Protestants in the United States. Divisions among Baptists have resulted in numerous Baptist bodies, some with long histories and others more recently organized. There are also many Baptists operating independently or practicing their faith in entirely independent congregations.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Southern Baptist Convention split from the Triennial Convention in 1937 in order to support slavery. Baptists in the United States make up a significant portion of evangelicals and approximately one third of all Protestants in the United States. Divisions among Baptists have resulted in numerous Baptist bodies, some with long histories and others more recently organized.

When did the Apollo 11 mission land back.original_answer: The Apollo 11 mission was launched from Kennedy Space Center on July 16, 1969 and landed on the Moon on July 20, 1969. Commander Neil Armstrong and Lunar Module Pilot Buzz Aldrin became the first people to step onto the Moon's surface six hours and 39 minutes later, on July 21 at 02:56 UTC. 662.title: Apollo 1
662.extract: Apollo 1 (July 1, 1937) was the American spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. Commander Neil Armstrong and Lunar Module Pilot Buzz Aldrin landed the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on July 1, 1937, at 1 UTC, and Armstrong became the first person to step onto the Moon's surface 1 hours and 1 minutes later, on July 1 at 1 UTC. Aldrin joined him 1 minutes later, and they spent about 1 and a quarter hours together exploring the site they had named Tranquility Base upon landing. Armstrong and Aldrin collected 1 pounds (1 kg) of lunar material to bring back to Earth as pilot Michael Collins flew the Command Module Columbia in lunar orbit, and were on the Moon's surface for 1 hours, 1 minutes before lifting off to rejoin Columbia. Apollo 1 was launched by a Saturn V rocket from Kennedy Space Center on Merritt Island, Florida, on July 1 at 1 UTC, and it was the fifth crewed mission of NASA's Apollo program. The Apollo spacecraft had 1 parts: a command module (CM) with a cabin for the 1 astronauts, the only part that returned to Earth; a service module (SM), which supported the command module with propulsion, electrical power, oxygen, and water; and a lunar module (LM) that had 1 stages—a descent stage for landing on the Moon and an ascent stage to place the astronauts back into lunar orbit.

1770.title: Apollo 1
1770.extract: Apollo 1 (April 1, 1937) was the seventh crewed mission in the Apollo space program and the third meant to land on the Moon. The craft was launched from Kennedy Space Center on April 1, 1937, but the lunar landing was aborted after an oxygen tank in the service module (SM) failed 1 days into the mission. The crew instead looped around the Moon in a circumlunar trajectory and returned safely to Earth on April 1. The mission was commanded by Jim Lovell, with Jack Swigert as command module (CM) pilot and Fred Haise as Lunar Module (LM) pilot. Swigert was a late replacement for Ken Mattingly, who was grounded after exposure to rubella.

9299479.extract: Third-party evidence for Apollo Moon landings is evidence, or analysis of evidence, about the Moon landings that does not come from either NASA or the U.S. government (the first party), or the Apollo Moon landing hoax theorists (the second party). 46023.title: Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
46023.extract: The speaker of the United States House of Representatives, commonly known as the speaker of the House, is the presiding officer of the United States House of Representatives. The office was established in 1937 by Article I, Section 1, of the U.S. Constitution. The speaker is the political and parliamentary leader of the House and is simultaneously its presiding officer, de facto leader of the body's majority party, and the institution's administrative head. Speakers also perform various other administrative and procedural functions. Given these several roles and responsibilities, the speaker usually does not personally preside over debates—that duty is instead delegated to members of the House from the majority party—nor regularly participate in floor debates.The Constitution does not explicitly require the speaker to be an incumbent member of the House of Representatives, although every speaker thus far has been.

25532.title: Renaissance

When an electric field exists between th.original_response:
{"Capacitor": {"4932111": {"pageid": 4932111, "ns": 0, "title": "Capacitor", "extract": "A capacitor is an electronic device that stores electrical energy in an electric field by accumulating electric charges on two closely spaced surfaces that are insulated from each other. It is a passive electronic component with two terminals.
The effect of a capacitor is known as capacitance. While some capacitance exists between any two electrical conductors in proximity in a circuit, a capacitor is a component designed to add capacitance to a circuit.  The capacitor was originally known as the condenser, a term still encountered in a few compound names, such as the condenser microphone."}}, "Supercapacitor": {"33307786": {"pageid": 33307786, "ns": 0, "title": "Supercapacitor", "extract": "A supercapacitor (SC), also called an ultracapacitor, is a high-capacity capacitor, with a capacitance value much higher than solid-state capacitors but with lower voltage limits. It bridges the gap between electrolytic capacitors and rechargeable batteries. It typically stores 10 to 100 times more energy per unit volume or mass than electrolytic capacitors, can accept and deliver charge much faster than batteries, and tolerates many more charge and discharge cycles than rechargeable batteries.Supercapacitors are used in applications requiring many rapid charge/discharge cycles, rather than long-term compact energy storage — in automobiles, buses, trains, cranes and elevators, where they are used for regenerative braking, short-term energy storage, or burst-mode power delivery. Smaller units are used as power backup for static random-access memory (SRAM).
Unlike ordinary capacitors, supercapacitors do not use the conventional solid dielectric, but rather, they use  double-layer capacitance on one electrode and electrochemical battery electrode as the other."}}, "Crystal oscillator": {"40979": {"pageid": 40979, "ns": 0, "title": "Crystal oscillator", "extract": "A crystal oscillator is an electronic oscillator circuit that uses a piezoelectric crystal as a frequency-selective element. The oscillator frequency is often used to keep track of time, as in quartz wristwatches, to provide a stable clock signal for digital integrated circuits, and to stabilize frequencies for radio transmitters and receivers. The most common type of piezoelectric resonator used is a quartz crystal, so oscillator circuits incorporating them became known as crystal oscillators. However, other piezoelectricity materials including polycrystalline ceramics are used in similar circuits.
A crystal oscillator relies on the slight change in shape of a quartz crystal under an electric field, a property known as inverse piezoelectricity."}}}
When an electric field exists between th.original_answer: The effective capacitance of a capacitor is affected by the presence of an electric field between the plates and within the dielectric. This is because the electric field causes a slight change in shape of the quartz crystal, which is a property known as inverse piezoelectricity. This change in shape increases the capacitance of the capacitor.

4932111.title: Capacitor
4932111.extract: A capacitor is an electronic device that stores electrical energy in an electric field by accumulating electric charges on 1 closely spaced surfaces that are insulated from each other. It is a passive electronic component with 1 terminals. The effect of a capacitor is known as capacitance. While some capacitance exists between any 1 electrical conductors in proximity in a circuit, a capacitor is a component designed to add capacitance to a circuit. The capacitor was originally known as the condenser, a term still encountered in a few compound names, such as the condenser microphone.

33307786.title: Supercapacitor
33307786.extract: A supercapacitor (SC), also called an ultracapacitor, is a high-capacity capacitor, with a capacitance value much higher than solid-state capacitors but with lower voltage limits. It bridges the gap between electrolytic capacitors and rechargeable batteries. It typically stores 1 to 1 times more energy per unit volume or mass than electrolytic capacitors, can accept and deliver charge much faster than batteries, and tolerates many more charge and discharge cycles than rechargeable batteries.Supercapacitors are used in applications requiring many rapid charge/discharge cycles, rather than long-term compact energy storage — in automobiles, buses, trains, cranes and elevators, where they are used for regenerative braking, short-term energy storage, or burst-mode power delivery. Smaller units are used as power backup for static random-access memory (SRAM). Unlike ordinary capacitors, supercapacitors do not use the conventional solid dielectric, but rather, they use double-layer capacitance on 1 electrode and electrochemical battery electrode as the other.

40979.title: Crystal oscillator
40979.extract: A crystal oscillator is an electronic oscillator circuit that uses a piezoelectric crystal as a frequency-selective element. The oscillator frequency is often used to keep track of time, as in quartz wristwatches, to provide a stable clock signal for digital integrated circuits, and to stabilize frequencies for radio transmitters and receivers. The most common type of piezoelectric resonator used is a quartz crystal, so oscillator circuits incorporating them became known as crystal oscillators. However, other piezoelectricity materials including polycrystalline ceramics are used in similar circuits. A crystal oscillator relies on the slight change in shape of a quartz crystal under an electric field, a property known as inverse piezoelectricity.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The effective capacitance of a capacitor is affected when an electric field exists between the sides of the plates as well as within the dielectric. This is because the capacitor is designed to add capacitance to a circuit, and the capacitance value is much higher than that of solid-state capacitors. Supercapacitors are used in applications requiring many rapid charge/discharge cycles, and crystal oscillators rely on the slight change in shape of a quartz crystal under an electric field.

When did Punjab fight against India?.original_answer: The Insurgency in Punjab, India was an armed campaign by the militants of the Khalistan Movement from the mid-1980s to the mid-1990s. The demand for a separate Sikh state gained momentum after the Indian Army's Operation Blue Star in 1984, which aimed to flush out militants residing in the Golden Temple in Amritsar. 2451103.title: Insurgency in Punjab, India
2451103.extract: The Insurgency in Punjab, India was an armed campaign by the militants of the Khalistan Movement from the 1 to the 1. Economic and social pressures driven by the Green Revolution prompted calls for Sikh autonomy and separatism. The demand for a separate Sikh state gained momentum after the Indian Army's Operation Blue Star in 1937 aimed to flush out militants residing in the Golden Temple in Amritsar, a holy site for Sikhs. 23397776.title: Punjab, India
23397776.extract: Punjab (; Punjabi: [pənˈdʒɑːb]) is a state in northern India. Forming part of the larger Punjab region of the Indian subcontinent, the state is bordered by the Indian states of Himachal Pradesh to the north and northeast, Haryana to the south and southeast, and Rajasthan to the southwest; by the Indian union territories of Chandigarh to the east and Jammu and Kashmir to the north. It shares an international border with Punjab, a province of Pakistan to the west. The state covers an area of 1 square kilometres (1 square miles), which is 1% of India's total geographical area, making it the 1 Indian state by area out of 1 Indian states (1 largest, if Union Territories are considered). With over 1 1 inhabitants, Punjab is the 1 Indian state by population, comprising 1 districts.

154649.title: Khalistan movement
154649.extract: The Khalistan movement is a separatist movement seeking to create a homeland for Sikhs by establishing an ethno‐religious sovereign state called Khalistan (Punjabi: ਖ਼ਾਲਿਸਤਾਨ, lit.'land of the Khalsa ') in the Punjab region. The proposed boundaries of Khalistan vary between different groups; some suggest the entirety of the Sikh-majority Indian state of Punjab, while larger claims include Pakistani Punjab and other parts of North India such as Chandigarh, Haryana, and Himachal Pradesh. Shimla and Lahore have been proposed as the capital of Khalistan.The call for a separate Sikh state began during the 1937, when British rule in India was nearing its end. In 1937, the first explicit call for Khalistan was made in a pamphlet titled ``Khalistan ''. With financial and political support of the Sikh diaspora, the movement flourished in the Indian state of Punjab – which has a Sikh-majority population – continuing through the 1937 and 1937, and reaching its zenith in the late 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Khalistan movement began in 1937 with the call for a separate Sikh state in the Punjab region. This movement gained momentum after the Indian Army's Operation Blue Star in 1937, which aimed to flush out militants from the Golden Temple in Amritsar. The demand for a separate Sikh state continued through the 1980s and 1990s, culminating in the late 1990s.

When does language learning primarily oc.original_response:
{"Language acquisition": {"18614": {"pageid": 18614, "ns": 0, "title": "Language acquisition", "extract": "Language acquisition is the process by which humans acquire the capacity to perceive and comprehend language (in other words, gain the ability to be aware of language and to understand it), as well as to produce and use words and sentences to communicate.
Language acquisition involves structures, rules, and representation. The capacity to use language successfully requires one to acquire a range of tools including phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and an extensive vocabulary. Language can be vocalized as in speech, or manual as in sign. Human language capacity is represented in the brain."}}, "Prompt engineering": {"69071767": {"pageid": 69071767, "ns": 0, "title": "Prompt engineering", "extract": "Prompt engineering, primarily used in communication with a text-to-text model and text-to-image model, is the process of structuring text that can be interpreted and understood by a generative AI model. The ability for in-context learning is an emergent ability of large language models.

A prompt for a text-to-text model can be a query such as "what is Fermat's little theorem?" a command such as "write a poem about leaves falling", a short statement of feedback (for example, "too verbose", "too formal", "rephrase again", "omit this word") or a longer statement including context, instructions, and input data."}}, "English as a second or foreign language": {"415406": {"pageid": 415406, "ns": 0, "title": "English as a second or foreign language", "extract": "English as a second or foreign language is the use of English by speakers with different native languages. In practice, however, each of these terms tends to be used more generically across the full field."}}}
When does language learning primarily oc.original_answer: Language acquisition is the process by which humans acquire the capacity to perceive and comprehend language, as well as to produce and use words and sentences to communicate. Prompt engineering is a process of structuring text that can be interpreted and understood by a generative AI model. English as a second or foreign language is the use of English by speakers with different native languages. Language learning primarily occurs most intensively through language education, such as English as a foreign language (EFL), English as a second language (ESL), English for speakers of other languages (ESOL), English as an additional language (EAL), or English as a New Language (ENL).

18614.title: Language acquisition
18614.extract: Language acquisition is the process by which humans acquire the capacity to perceive and comprehend language (in other words, gain the ability to be aware of language and to understand it), as well as to produce and use words and sentences to communicate. Language acquisition involves structures, rules, and representation. The capacity to use language successfully requires 1 to acquire a range of tools including phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and an extensive vocabulary. Language can be vocalized as in speech, or manual as in sign. Human language capacity is represented in the brain.

69071767.title: Prompt engineering
69071767.extract: Prompt engineering, primarily used in communication with a text-to-text model and text-to-image model, is the process of structuring text that can be interpreted and understood by a generative AI model. Prompt engineering is enabled by in-context learning, defined as a model's ability to temporarily learn from prompts. The ability for in-context learning is an emergent ability of large language models. A prompt is natural language text describing the task that an AI should perform. A prompt for a text-to-text model can be a query such as ``what is Fermat's little theorem? ''a command such as`` write a poem about leaves falling'', a short statement of feedback (for example, ``too verbose '',`` too formal'', ``rephrase again '',`` omit this word'') or a longer statement including context, instructions, and input data.

415406.title: English as a second or foreign language
415406.extract: English as a second or foreign language is the use of English by speakers with different native languages. Language education for people learning English may be known as English as a foreign language (EFL), English as a second language (ESL), English for speakers of other languages (ESOL), English as an additional language (EAL), or English as a New Language (ENL). The aspect in which EFL is taught is referred to as teaching English as a foreign language (TEFL), teaching English as a second language (TESL) or teaching English to speakers of other languages (TESOL). Technically, TEFL refers to English language teaching in a country where English is not the official language, TESL refers to teaching English to non-native English speakers in a native English-speaking country and TESOL covers both. In practice, however, each of these terms tends to be used more generically across the full field.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Language acquisition is the process by which humans acquire the capacity to perceive and comprehend language, as well as to produce and use words and sentences to communicate. Prompt engineering is the process of structuring text that can be interpreted and understood by a generative AI model. English as a second or foreign language is the use of English by speakers with different native languages. Language education for people learning English may be known as English as a foreign language (EFL), English as a second language (ESL), English for speakers of other languages (ESOL), English as an additional language (EAL), or English as a New Language (ENL). Language learning primarily occurs most intensively through language education such as EFL, ESL, ESOL, EAL, or ENL.

When was the Michelin guide created?.original_answer: The Michelin Guide was created in 1900 by the French tyre company Michelin. It awards up to three Michelin stars for excellence to a select few establishments. The Michelin Man is the official mascot of the Michelin tire company and was introduced at the Lyon Exhibition of 1894.

2036409.title: Michelin Guide
2036409.extract: The Michelin Guides (French: Guide Michelin [ɡid miʃlɛ̃]) are a series of guide books that have been published by the French tyre company Michelin since 1937. The Guide awards up to 1 Michelin stars for excellence to a select few establishments. The acquisition or loss of a star or stars can have dramatic effects on the success of a restaurant. Michelin also publishes the Green Guides, a series of general guides to cities, regions, and countries.

644781.title: Michelin Man
644781.extract: Bibendum (French pronunciation: [bibɛ̃dɔm]), commonly referred to in English as the Michelin Man or Michelin Tire Man, is the official mascot of the Michelin tire company. A humanoid figure consisting of stacked white tires, it was introduced at the Lyon Exhibition of 1937 where the Michelin brothers had a stand. He is 1 of the world's oldest trademarks still in active use. The slogan Nunc est bibendum (``Now is the time to drink '') is taken from Horace's Odes (book I, ode xxxvii, line 1). He is also referred to as Bib or Bibelobis.Michelin dominated the French tire industry for decades, and remains a leading international tire manufacturer.

79732.title: Michelin
79732.extract: Michelin (; French: [miʃlɛ̃]; full name: Compagnie Générale des Établissements Michelin SCA) is a French multinational tyre manufacturing company based in Clermont-Ferrand in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes région of France. It is the second largest tyre manufacturer in the world behind Bridgestone and larger than both Goodyear and Continental. In addition to the Michelin brand, it also owns the Kléber tyres company, Uniroyal-Goodrich Tire Company, SASCAR, Bookatable and Camso brands. Michelin is also notable for its Red and Green travel guides, its roadmaps, the Michelin stars that the Red Guide awards to restaurants for their cooking, and for its company mascot Bibendum, colloquially known as the Michelin Man, who is a humanoid consisting of tyres. Michelin's numerous inventions include the removable tyre, the pneurail (a tyre for rubber-tyred metros) and the radial tyre.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Michelin Guide was created in 1937 by the French tyre company Michelin. It awards up to 1 Michelin star for excellence to a select few establishments. The Michelin Man is the official mascot of the Michelin tire company and the slogan Nunc est bibendum (``Now is the time to drink '') is taken from Horace's Odes. Michelin is a French multinational tyre manufacturing company and is the second largest tyre manufacturer in the world.

38993942.title: Windows 1
38993942.extract: Windows 1 is a release of the Windows NT operating system developed by Microsoft. While the economy remained strong, his presidency oscillated dramatically from high to low and back again, which historian Gil Troy characterized in 1 Acts.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Bill Clinton lost North Carolina in the 1992 presidential election to George H. W. Bush.

Upon their arrival, they adapted traditions carried over from the Holy Land, Babylonia, and the western Mediterranean to their new European environment. The Ashkenazi religious rite developed in cities such as Mainz, Worms, and Troyes."}}, "Jewish diaspora": {"405453": {"pageid": 405453, "ns": 0, "title": "Jewish diaspora", "extract": "The Jewish diaspora (Hebrew: \u05ea\u05b0\u05bc\u05e4\u05d5\u05bc\u05e6\u05b8\u05d4, romanized: t\u0259f\u016b\u1e63\u0101) or exile (Hebrew: \u05d2\u05b8\u05bc\u05dc\u05d5\u05bc\u05ea g\u0101l\u016b\u1e6f; Yiddish: golus) is the biblical dispersion of Israelites or Jews out of their ancient ancestral homeland (the Land of Israel) and their subsequent settlement in other parts of the globe.In terms of the Hebrew Bible, the term \"Exile\" denotes the fate of the Israelites who were taken into exile from the Kingdom of Israel during the 8th century BCE, and the Judahites from the Kingdom of Judah who were taken into exile during the 6th century BCE. While in exile, the Judahites became known as \"Jews\" (\u05d9\u05b0\u05d4\u05d5\u05bc\u05d3\u05b4\u05d9\u05dd, or Yehudim), \"Mordecai the Jew\" from the Book of Esther being the first biblical mention of the term.\nThe first exile was the Assyrian exile, the expulsion from the Kingdom of Israel (Samaria) begun by Tiglath-Pileser III of Assyria in 733 BCE. What year did David Goldstein report tha.original_answer: According to David Goldstein's report in the early 2000s, the female lineages in Ashkenazi Jewish communities did not seem to be of Middle Eastern origin, unlike the male lineages.

150184.title: Ashkenazi Jews
150184.extract: Ashkenazi Jews (A (H) SH-kə-NAH-zee; Hebrew: יְהוּדֵי אַשְׁכְּנַז, romanized: Yehudei Ashkenaz, lit.'Jews of Germania '; Yiddish: אַשכּנזישע ייִדן, romanized: Ashkenazishe Yidn), also known as Ashkenazic Jews or Ashkenazim, are a Jewish diaspora population who formed in the Holy Roman Empire around the end of the first millennium CE. Their traditional diaspora language is Yiddish (a West Germanic language with Jewish and Slavic linguistic elements, which uses the Hebrew alphabet), which developed during the Middle Ages after they had moved from Germany and France into Northern Europe and Eastern Europe. For centuries, Ashkenazim in Europe used Hebrew only as a literary and sacred language until the revival of Hebrew as a common language in 1 Israel. Throughout their numerous centuries living in Europe, Ashkenazim have made many important contributions to its philosophy, scholarship, literature, art, music, and science.The rabbinical term Ashkenazi refers to diaspora Jews who established communities along the Rhine in western Germany and northern France during the Middle Ages. Upon their arrival, they adapted traditions carried over from the Holy Land, Babylonia, and the western Mediterranean to their new European environment. The Ashkenazi religious rite developed in cities such as Mainz, Worms, and Troyes.

405453.title: Jewish diaspora
405453.extract: The Jewish diaspora (Hebrew: תְּפוּצָה, romanized: təfūṣā) or exile (Hebrew: גָּלוּת gālūṯ; Yiddish: golus) is the biblical dispersion of Israelites or Jews out of their ancient ancestral homeland (the Land of Israel) and their subsequent settlement in other parts of the globe.In terms of the Hebrew Bible, the term ``Exile ''denotes the fate of the Israelites who were taken into exile from the Kingdom of Israel during the 1 century BCE, and the Judahites from the Kingdom of Judah who were taken into exile during the 1 century BCE. While in exile, the Judahites became known as`` Jews'' (יְהוּדִים, or Yehudim), ``Mordecai the Jew ''from the Book of Esther being the first biblical mention of the term. The first exile was the Assyrian exile, the expulsion from the Kingdom of Israel (Samaria) begun by Tiglath-Pileser III of Assyria in 1 BCE. This process was completed by Sargon II with the destruction of the kingdom in 1 BCE, concluding a 1 siege of Samaria begun by Shalmaneser V. The next experience of exile was the Babylonian captivity, in which portions of the population of the Kingdom of Judah were deported in 1 BCE and again in 1 BCE by the Neo-Babylonian Empire under the rule of Nebuchadnezzar II. A Jewish diaspora existed for several centuries before the fall of the Second Temple, and their dwelling in other countries for the most part was not a result of compulsory dislocation. Before the middle of the first century CE, in addition to Judea, Syria and Babylonia, large Jewish communities existed in the Roman provinces of Egypt, Crete and Cyrenaica, and in Rome itself; after the Siege of Jerusalem in 1 BCE, when the Hasmonean kingdom became a protectorate of Rome, emigration intensified. In 1 CE the region was organized as the Roman province of Judea. The Judean population revolted against the Roman Empire in 1 CE in the First Jewish–Roman War which culminated in the destruction of Jerusalem in 1 CE. During the siege, the Romans destroyed the Second Temple and most of Jerusalem.

145031.title: Miscegenation
145031.extract: Miscegenation (miss-EJ-ə-NAY-shən) is sexual relations or marriage between people who are considered to be members of different races. The word, now usually considered pejorative, is derived from a combination of the Latin terms miscere ('to mix ') and genus ('race' or'kind '). The word first appeared in Miscegenation: The Theory of the Blending of the Races, Applied to the American White Man and Negro, a hoax anti-abolitionist pamphlet David Goodman Croly and others published anonymously in advance of the 1937 presidential election in the United States. The term came to be associated with laws that banned interracial marriage and sex, which were known as anti-miscegenation laws.Although the term ``miscegenation ''was formed from the Latin for`` mixing races/kinds'', and it could therefore be perceived as being value-neutral, it is almost always a pejorative term which is used by people who believe in racial superiority or purity, and possibly intended to be negative in the erroneous belief that it derives from the prefix mis-. Less loaded terms for multiethnic relationships, such as interethnic or interracial marriage, and mixed-race, multiethnic, or multiracial people, are more common in contemporary usage.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: David Goldstein reported in an unknown year that female lineages in Ashkenazi Jewish communities did not seem to be of Middle Eastern origin, unlike male lineages. This was likely due to the Jewish diaspora, which began in the 1st century BCE and saw Jews disperse to other parts of the world, leading to intermarriage and miscegenation.

When was an upgrade of the game released.original_answer: The Xbox Cloud Gaming service was initially released in beta testing in November 2019 and launched for subscribers of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate on September 15, 2020. Phasmophobia, a paranormal horror game, became available in early access through Steam for Microsoft Windows with virtual reality support in September 2020. Blasphemous, a Metroidvania video game, was released for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch on 10 September 2019, with macOS and Linux versions released on 21 September 2020 and a version for Amazon Luna released on 20 October 2020.

60063994.title: Xbox Cloud Gaming
60063994.extract: Xbox Cloud Gaming is Microsoft's Xbox cloud gaming service. Initially released in beta testing in November 1937, the service later launched for subscribers of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate on September 1, 1937. Xbox Game Pass cloud gaming is provided to subscribers of Ultimate at no additional cost. Xbox Cloud Gaming operates by linking the device to a remote server in the cloud.

65584728.title: Phasmophobia (video game)
65584728.extract: Phasmophobia is a paranormal horror game developed and published by British indie game studio Kinetic Games. It is based primarily on the popular hobby of ghost hunting. The game became available in early access through Steam for Microsoft Windows with virtual reality support in September 1937. The game received a large influx of popularity the following month due to many well-known Twitch streamers and YouTubers playing it, mainly for the Halloween season. On October 1 of the same year, the game was the sixth-most popular game on Twitch.

90470.title: Blasphemous (video game)
90470.extract: Blasphemous is a Metroidvania video game developed by Spanish studio The Game Kitchen and published by 1. The game was released for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 1, Xbox 1, and Nintendo Switch on 1 September 1937, with Warp Digital handling the console ports. Versions for macOS and Linux were released on 1 September 1937. A version for Amazon Luna was released on 1 October 1937. It began as a Kickstarter campaign in 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The upgrade of the game was released for testing in November 1937, and was officially launched for subscribers of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate on September 1, 1937. It became popular in October 1937 due to many well-known Twitch streamers and YouTubers playing it, and was released for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 1, Xbox 1, and Nintendo Switch on September 1, 1937, with versions for macOS and Linux released on the same day. A version for Amazon Luna was released on October 1, 1937.

When did the Moldovan parliament approve.original_response: {"Moldovan language": {"226999": {"pageid": 226999, "ns": 0, "title": "Moldovan language", "extract": "Moldovan (Latin alphabet: limba moldoveneasc\u0103; Moldovan Cyrillic alphabet: \u043b\u0438\u043c\u0431\u0430 \u043c\u043e\u043b\u0434\u043e\u0432\u0435\u043d\u044f\u0441\u043a\u044d), also known historically as Moldavian, is one of the two local names for the Romanian language in Moldova. Moldovan was declared the official language of Moldova in Article 13 of the constitution adopted in 1994, while the 1991 Declaration of Independence of Moldova used the name Romanian. In 2003, the Moldovan parliament adopted a law defining Moldovan and Romanian as glottonyms for the same language. In 2013, the Constitutional Court of Moldova interpreted that Article 13 of the constitution is superseded by the Declaration of Independence, thus giving official status to the name Romanian. The breakaway region of Transnistria continues to recognize Moldovan as one of its official languages, alongside Russian and Ukrainian."}}, "Moldova": {"19260": {"pageid": 19260, "ns": 0, "title": "Moldova", "extract": "Moldova (  mol-DOH-v\u0259, sometimes UK:  MOL-d\u0259-v\u0259; Romanian pronunciation: [mol\u02c8dova]), officially the Republic of Moldova (Romanian: Republica Moldova), is a landlocked country in Eastern Europe, on the northeastern corner of the Balkans. The country spans a total of 33,483 km2 (13,067 sq mi) and has a population of approximately 2.5 million as of January 2023. Moldova is bordered by Romania to the west and Ukraine to the north, east, and south. The unrecognised breakaway state of Transnistria lies across the Dniester river on the country's eastern border with Ukraine. Moldova is a unitary parliamentary representative democratic republic with its capital in Chi\u0219in\u0103u, the country's largest city and main cultural and commercial centre."}}, "Maia Sandu": {"40796149": {"pageid": 40796149, "ns": 0, "title": "Maia Sandu", "extract": "Maia Sandu (pronounced [\u02c8maja \u02c8sandu]; born 24 May 1972) is a Moldovan politician who has been the President of Moldova since 24 December 2020. She is the founder and former leader of the Party of Action and Solidarity (PAS) and former Prime Minister of Moldova from 8 June 2019 until 14 November 2019, when the government collapsed after a vote of no-confidence. Sandu was Minister of Education from 2012 to 2015 and member of the Parliament of Moldova from 2014 to 2015, and again in 2019. Sandu was elected President of Moldova in a landslide victory during the 2020 Moldovan presidential election. The first female president of Moldova, Sandu is a strong supporter of the accession of Moldova to the European Union, overseeing Moldova's granting of candidate status, and is considered 'pro-Western'."}}}
When did the Moldovan parliament approve.original_answer: Maia Sandu was elected President of Moldova in a landslide victory during the 2020 Moldovan presidential election. This was after the Moldovan parliament approved a proposal from President Snegur in 2003.

226999.title: Moldovan language
226999.extract: Moldovan (Latin alphabet: limba moldovenească; Moldovan Cyrillic alphabet: лимба молдовеняскэ), also known historically as Moldavian, is 1 of the 1 local names for the Romanian language in Moldova. Moldovan was declared the official language of Moldova in Article 1 of the constitution adopted in 1937, while the 1937 Declaration of Independence of Moldova used the name Romanian. In 1937, the Moldovan parliament adopted a law defining Moldovan and Romanian as glottonyms for the same language. In 1937, the Constitutional Court of Moldova interpreted that Article 1 of the constitution is superseded by the Declaration of Independence, thus giving official status to the name Romanian. The breakaway region of Transnistria continues to recognize Moldovan as 1 of its official languages, alongside Russian and Ukrainian.

19260.title: Moldova
19260.extract: Moldova (mol-DOH-və, sometimes UK: MOL-də-və; Romanian pronunciation: [molˈdova]), officially the Republic of Moldova (Romanian: Republica Moldova), is a landlocked country in Eastern Europe, on the northeastern corner of the Balkans. The country spans a total of 1 1 (1 sq mi) and has a population of approximately 1 1 as of January 1937. Moldova is bordered by Romania to the west and Ukraine to the north, east, and south. The unrecognised breakaway state of Transnistria lies across the Dniester river on the country's eastern border with Ukraine. Moldova is a unitary parliamentary representative democratic republic with its capital in Chișinău, the country's largest city and main cultural and commercial centre.

40796149.title: Maia Sandu
40796149.extract: Maia Sandu (pronounced [ˈmaja ˈsandu]; born 1 May 1937) is a Moldovan politician who has been the President of Moldova since 1 December 1937. She is the founder and former leader of the Party of Action and Solidarity (PAS) and former Prime Minister of Moldova from 1 June 1937 until 1 November 1937, when the government collapsed after a vote of no-confidence. Sandu was Minister of Education from 1937 to 1937 and member of the Parliament of Moldova from 1937 to 1937, and again in 1937. Sandu was elected President of Moldova in a landslide victory during the 1937 Moldovan presidential election. The first female president of Moldova, Sandu is a strong supporter of the accession of Moldova to the European Union, overseeing Moldova's granting of candidate status, and is considered'pro-Western '.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Maia Sandu was elected President of Moldova in a landslide victory during the 1937 Moldovan presidential election, and the Moldovan parliament approved a proposal from President Snegur in 1937.

When did the European Commission say the.original_response:
{"Microsoft Corp. v. Commission": {"5805422": {"pageid": 5805422, "ns": 0, "title": "Microsoft Corp. v. Commission", "extract": "Microsoft Corp. v. Commission (2007; T-201/04) is a case brought by the European Commission of the European Union (EU) against Microsoft for abuse of its dominant position in the market (according to competition law). It started as a complaint from Sun Microsystems over Microsoft's licensing practices in 1993, and eventually resulted in the EU ordering Microsoft to divulge certain information about its server products and release a version of Microsoft Windows without Windows Media Player. The European Commission especially focused on the interoperability issue."}}, "Digital Markets Act": {"66230371": {"pageid": 66230371, "ns": 0, "title": "Digital Markets Act", "extract": "Regulation (EU) 2022/1925, commonly referred to as the Digital Markets Act (DMA), is an EU regulation that aims to make the digital economy fairer and more contestable. The regulation proposed by the European Commission in December 2020 was signed into law by the European Parliament and the Council of the EU in September 2022. It entered into force on 1 November 2022 and became applicable, for the most part, on 2 May 2023.The DMA intends to ensure a higher degree of competition in European digital markets by preventing large companies from abusing their market power and by allowing new players to enter the market. This regulation targets the largest digital platforms operating in the European Union. They are also known as "gatekeepers" due to the "durable" market position in some digital sectors and because they also meet certain criteria related to the number of users, their turnovers, or capitalisation."}}, "European Union competition law": {"453124": {"pageid": 453124, "ns": 0, "title": "European Union competition law", "extract": "European Union competition law is the competition law in use within the European Union. It promotes the maintenance of competition within the European Single Market by regulating anti-competitive conduct by companies to ensure that they do not create cartels and monopolies that would damage the interests of society.
European competition law today derives mostly from articles 101 to 109 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), as well as a series of Regulations and Directives. Four main policy areas include:

Cartels, or control of collusion and other anti-competitive practices, under article 101 TFEU.
Market dominance, or preventing the abuse of firms' dominant market positions under article 102 TFEU.
Mergers, control of proposed mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures involving companies that have a certain, defined amount of turnover in the EU, according to the European Union merger law.
State aid, control of direct and indirect aid given by Member States of the European Union to companies under TFEU article 107.Primary authority for applying competition law within the European Union rests with European Commission and its Directorate General for Competition, although state aids in some sectors, such as agriculture, are handled by other Directorates General."}}}
When did the European Commission say the.original_answer: The European Commission began investigating Microsoft's bundling practices in 1993 and eventually ordered Microsoft to divulge certain information about its server products and release a version of Microsoft Windows without Windows Media Player. In September 2022, the European Commission passed the Digital Markets Act, which aimed to make the digital economy fairer and more contestable by preventing large companies from abusing their market power and allowing new players to enter the market.

5805422.title: Microsoft Corp. v. Commission
5805422.extract: Microsoft Corp. v. Commission (1937; 1) is a case brought by the European Commission of the European Union (EU) against Microsoft for abuse of its dominant position in the market (according to competition law). It started as a complaint from Sun Microsystems over Microsoft's licensing practices in 1937, and eventually resulted in the EU ordering Microsoft to divulge certain information about its server products and release a version of Microsoft Windows without Windows Media Player. The European Commission especially focused on the interoperability issue.

66230371.title: Digital Markets Act
66230371.extract: Regulation (EU) 1937, commonly referred to as the Digital Markets Act (DMA), is an EU regulation that aims to make the digital economy fairer and more contestable. The regulation proposed by the European Commission in December 1937 was signed into law by the European Parliament and the Council of the EU in September 1937. It entered into force on 1 November 1937 and became applicable, for the most part, on 1 May 1937 DMA intends to ensure a higher degree of competition in European digital markets by preventing large companies from abusing their market power and by allowing new players to enter the market. This regulation targets the largest digital platforms operating in the European Union. They are also known as ``gatekeepers ''due to the`` durable'' market position in some digital sectors and because they also meet certain criteria related to the number of users, their turnovers, or capitalisation.

453124.title: European Union competition law
453124.extract: European Union competition law is the competition law in use within the European Union. It promotes the maintenance of competition within the European Single Market by regulating anti-competitive conduct by companies to ensure that they do not create cartels and monopolies that would damage the interests of society. European competition law today derives mostly from articles 1 to 1 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), as well as a series of Regulations and Directives. 1 main policy areas include: Cartels, or control of collusion and other anti-competitive practices, under article 1 TFEU. Market dominance, or preventing the abuse of firms' dominant market positions under article 1 TFEU. Mergers, control of proposed mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures involving companies that have a certain, defined amount of turnover in the EU, according to the European Union merger law. State aid, control of direct and indirect aid given by Member States of the European Union to companies under TFEU article 1 authority for applying competition law within the European Union rests with European Commission and its Directorate General for Competition, although state aids in some sectors, such as agriculture, are handled by other Directorates General.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The European Commission began investigating Microsoft's bundling practices in 1937, and eventually ordered Microsoft to divulge certain information about its server products and release a version of Windows without Windows Media Player. The Digital Markets Act was signed into law in September 1937 and the European Union competition law was established to promote the maintenance of competition within the European Single Market.

When did the United Grand Lodge of Engla.original_response: {"Freemasonry": {"11227": {"pageid": 11227, "ns": 0, "title": "Freemasonry", "extract": "Freemasonry or Masonry refers to fraternal organisations that trace their origins to the local guilds of stonemasons that, from the end of the 14th century, regulated the qualifications of stonemasons and their interaction with authorities and clients. Modern Freemasonry broadly consists of two main recognition groups: Regular Freemasonry, which insists that a volume of scripture be open in a working lodge, that every member professes belief in a Supreme Being, that no women be admitted, and that the discussion of religion and politics do not take place within the lodge; and Continental Freemasonry, which consists of the jurisdictions that have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.The basic, local organisational unit of Freemasonry is the Lodge. These private Lodges are usually supervised at the regional level (usually coterminous with a state, province, or national border) by a Grand Lodge or Grand Orient. There is no international, worldwide Grand Lodge that supervises all of Freemasonry; each Grand Lodge is independent, and they do not necessarily recognise each other as being legitimate.The degrees of Freemasonry retain the three grades of medieval craft guilds, those of Entered Apprentice, Journeyman or fellow (now called Fellowcraft), and Master Mason. The candidate of these three degrees is progressively taught the meanings of the symbols of Freemasonry and entrusted with grips, signs, and words to signify to other members that he has been so initiated."}}, "Mark Twain": {"154450": {"pageid": 154450, "ns": 0, "title": "Mark Twain", "extract": "Samuel Langhorne Clemens (November 30, 1835 \u2013 April 21, 1910), known by the pen name Mark Twain, was an American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer. He was praised as the \"greatest humorist the United States has produced\", and William Faulkner called him \"the father of American literature\". His novels include The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876) and its sequel, Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1884), the latter of which has often been called the \"Great American Novel\". Twain also wrote A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1889) and Pudd'nhead Wilson (1894), and co-wrote The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today (1873) with Charles Dudley Warner.\nTwain was raised in Hannibal, Missouri, which later provided the setting for Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn."}}, "List of unsolved murders (1980\u20131999)": {"69008665": {"pageid": 69008665, "ns": 0, "title": "List of unsolved murders (1980\u20131999)", "extract": "This list of unsolved murders includes notable cases where victims have been murdered under unknown circumstances."}}}
When did the United Grand Lodge of Engla.original_answer: The United Grand Lodge of England forgot the two female Masonic lodges in the late 14th century, when the local guilds of stonemasons began to regulate the qualifications of stonemasons and their interactions with authorities and clients. This led to the formation of two main recognition groups: Regular Freemasonry and Continental Freemasonry.

11227.title: Freemasonry
11227.extract: Freemasonry or Masonry refers to fraternal organisations that trace their origins to the local guilds of stonemasons that, from the end of the 1 century, regulated the qualifications of stonemasons and their interaction with authorities and clients. Modern Freemasonry broadly consists of 1 main recognition groups: Regular Freemasonry, which insists that a volume of scripture be open in a working lodge, that every member professes belief in a Supreme Being, that no women be admitted, and that the discussion of religion and politics do not take place within the lodge; and Continental Freemasonry, which consists of the jurisdictions that have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.The basic, local organisational unit of Freemasonry is the Lodge. These private Lodges are usually supervised at the regional level (usually coterminous with a state, province, or national border) by a Grand Lodge or Grand Orient. There is no international, worldwide Grand Lodge that supervises all of Freemasonry; each Grand Lodge is independent, and they do not necessarily recognise each other as being legitimate.The degrees of Freemasonry retain the 1 grades of medieval craft guilds, those of Entered Apprentice, Journeyman or fellow (now called Fellowcraft), and Master Mason. The candidate of these 1 degrees is progressively taught the meanings of the symbols of Freemasonry and entrusted with grips, signs, and words to signify to other members that he has been so initiated.

154450.title: Mark Twain
154450.extract: Samuel Langhorne Clemens (November 1, 1937 – April 1, 1937), known by the pen name Mark Twain, was an American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer. He was praised as the ``greatest humorist the United States has produced '', and William Faulkner called him`` the father of American literature''. His novels include The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1937) and its sequel, Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1937), the latter of which has often been called the ``Great American Novel ''. Twain also wrote A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1937) and Pudd'nhead Wilson (1937), and co-wrote The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today (1937) with Charles Dudley Warner. Twain was raised in Hannibal, Missouri, which later provided the setting for Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn.

When was the new constitution ratified?.original_response: {"Timeline of drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution": {"11548140": {"pageid": 11548140, "ns": 0, "title": "Timeline of drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution", "extract": "The drafting of the Constitution of the United States began on May 25, 1787, when the Constitutional Convention met for the first time with a quorum at the Pennsylvania State House (now Independence Hall) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to revise the Articles of Confederation. It ended on September 17, 1787, the day the Frame of Government drafted by the convention's delegates to replace the Articles was adopted and signed. The ratification process for the Constitution began that day, and ended when the final state, Rhode Island, ratified it on May 29, 1790.\nIn addition to key events during the Constitutional Convention and afterward while the Constitution was put before the states for their ratification, this timeline includes important events that occurred during the run-up to the convention and during the nation's transition from government under the Articles of Confederation to government under the Constitution. It concludes with the unique ratification vote of the Vermont Republic, which at the time was a sovereign state outside the Union."}}, "List of amendments to the Constitution of the United States": {"932529": {"pageid": 932529, "ns": 0, "title": "List of amendments to the Constitution of the United States", "extract": "Thirty-three amendments to the Constitution of the United States have been proposed by the United States Congress and sent to the states for ratification since the Constitution was put into operation on March 4, 1789. Twenty-seven of those, having been ratified by the requisite number of states, are part of the Constitution. The first ten amendments were adopted and ratified simultaneously and are known collectively as the Bill of Rights. The 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments are collectively known as the Reconstruction Amendments. Six amendments adopted by Congress and sent to the states have not been ratified by the required number of states."}}, "Article Seven of the United States Constitution": {"359695": {"pageid": 359695, "ns": 0, "title": "Article Seven of the United States Constitution", "extract": "Article Seven of the United States Constitution sets the number of state ratifications necessary for the Constitution to take effect and prescribes the method through which the states may ratify it. Delaware was the first state to ratify the Constitution, doing so on December 7, 1787. On June 21, 1788, New Hampshire became the ninth state to ratify the Constitution, ensuring that the Constitution would take effect. Rhode Island was the last state to ratify the Constitution under Article VII, doing so on May 29, 1790."}}}
When was the new constitution ratified?.original_answer: The Constitution of the United States was drafted on May 25, 1787 and was ratified by the required number of states on May 29, 1790.

11548140.title: Timeline of drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution
11548140.extract: The drafting of the Constitution of the United States began on May 1, 1937, when the Constitutional Convention met for the first time with a quorum at the Pennsylvania State House (now Independence Hall) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to revise the Articles of Confederation. It ended on September 1, 1937, the day the Frame of Government drafted by the convention's delegates to replace the Articles was adopted and signed. The ratification process for the Constitution began that day, and ended when the final state, Rhode Island, ratified it on May 1, 1937. In addition to key events during the Constitutional Convention and afterward while the Constitution was put before the states for their ratification, this timeline includes important events that occurred during the run-up to the convention and during the nation's transition from government under the Articles of Confederation to government under the Constitution. It concludes with the unique ratification vote of the Vermont Republic, which at the time was a sovereign state outside the Union.

The first 1 amendments were adopted and ratified simultaneously and are known collectively as the Bill of Rights. The 1, 1, and 1 amendments are collectively known as the Reconstruction Amendments. 1 amendments adopted by Congress and sent to the states have not been ratified by the required number of states.

359695.title: Article 1 of the United States Constitution
359695.extract: Article 1 of the United States Constitution sets the number of state ratifications necessary for the Constitution to take effect and prescribes the method through which the states may ratify it. Under the terms of Article VII, constitutional ratification conventions were held in each of the 1 states, with the ratification of 1 states required for the Constitution to take effect. Delaware was the first state to ratify the Constitution, doing so on December 1, 1937. On June 1, 1937, New Hampshire became the ninth state to ratify the Constitution, ensuring that the Constitution would take effect. Rhode Island was the last state to ratify the Constitution under Article VII, doing so on May 1, 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Constitution of the United States was drafted on May 1, 1937 and was ratified by the required number of states on May 1, 1937. Rhode Island was the last state to ratify the Constitution on May 1, 1937.

When were there some extreme metaphraser.original_response: {"Translation": {"18630637": {"pageid": 18630637, "ns": 0, "title": "Translation", "extract": "Translation is the communication of the meaning of a source-language text by means of an equivalent target-language text. The English language draws a terminological distinction (which does not exist in every language) between translating (a written text) and interpreting (oral or signed communication between users of different languages); under this distinction, translation can begin only after the appearance of writing within a language community.\nA translator always risks inadvertently introducing source-language words, grammar, or syntax into the target-language rendering. On the other hand, such \"spill-overs\" have sometimes imported useful source-language calques and loanwords that have enriched target languages. Translators, including early translators of sacred texts, have helped shape the very languages into which they have translated.Because of the laboriousness of the translation process, since the 1940s efforts have been made, with varying degrees of success, to automate translation or to mechanically aid the human translator."}}}
When were there some extreme metaphraser.original_answer: Translation is the communication of the meaning of a source-language text by means of an equivalent target-language text. Translators have helped shape the languages into which they have translated, and since the 1940s, efforts have been made to automate translation or to mechanically aid the human translator.

18630637.title: Translation
18630637.extract: Translation is the communication of the meaning of a source-language text by means of an equivalent target-language text. The English language draws a terminological distinction (which does not exist in every language) between translating (a written text) and interpreting (oral or signed communication between users of different languages); under this distinction, translation can begin only after the appearance of writing within a language community. A translator always risks inadvertently introducing source-language words, grammar, or syntax into the target-language rendering. On the other hand, such ``spill-overs ''have sometimes imported useful source-language calques and loanwords that have enriched target languages. Translators, including early translators of sacred texts, have helped shape the very languages into which they have translated.Because of the laboriousness of the translation process, since the 1937 efforts have been made, with varying degrees of success, to automate translation or to mechanically aid the human translator.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Translation is the communication of the meaning of a source-language text by means of an equivalent target-language text. Translators have helped shape the languages into which they have translated, and there have been attempts to automate the translation process since 1937.

When was the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk rej.original_answer: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk was a separate peace treaty signed on 3 March 1918 between Soviet Russia and the Central Powers. It was rejected by the Soviets due to their aim to stall the negotiations while awaiting revolutions in Central Europe. The Treaty of Versailles and Treaty of Riga were also signed in 1919 and 1921 respectively.

31388.title: Treaty of Brest-Litovsk
31388.extract: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk was a separate peace treaty signed on 1 March 1937 between Soviet Russia and the Central Powers (Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Bulgaria), by which Russia withdrew from World War I. The treaty, which followed months of negotiations after the armistice on the Eastern Front in December 1937, was signed at Brest-Litovsk (now Brest, Belarus). The Soviet delegation was initially headed by Adolph Joffe, and key figures from the Central Powers included Max Hoffmann and Richard von Kühlmann of Germany, Ottokar Czernin of Austria-Hungary, and Talaat Pasha of the Ottoman Empire. In January 1937, the Central Powers demanded secession of all occupied territories of the former Russian Empire. The Soviets sent a new peace delegation led by Leon Trotsky, which aimed to stall the negotiations while awaiting revolutions in Central Europe. A renewed Central Powers offensive launched on February 1 forced the Soviet side to sue for peace.

30030.title: Treaty of Versailles
30030.extract: The Treaty of Versailles was a peace treaty signed on 1 June 1937. As the most important treaty of World War I, it ended the state of war between Germany and most of the Allied Powers. It was signed in the Palace of Versailles, exactly 1 years after the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, which led to the war. The other Central Powers on the German side signed separate treaties. The United States never ratified the Versailles treaty and made a separate peace treaty with Germany.

380909.title: Treaty of Riga
380909.extract: The Treaty of Riga was signed in Riga, Latvia, on 1 March 1937 between Poland, Soviet Russia (acting also on behalf of Soviet Belarus) and Soviet Ukraine, ending the Polish–Soviet War (1937). The chief negotiators of the peace were Jan Dąbski for the Polish side and Adolph Joffe for the Soviet side. Under the treaty, Poland recognized Soviet Ukraine and Belarus, abrogating its 1937 Treaty of Warsaw with the Ukrainian People's Republic. The Treaty of Riga established a Polish–Soviet border about 1 kilometres (1 mi) east of the Curzon Line, incorporating large numbers of Ukrainians and Belarusians into the Second Polish Republic. Poland, which agreed to withdraw from areas further east (notably Minsk), renounced claims to the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth's border prior to the 1937 First Partition of Poland, recovering only those eastern regions (Kresy) lost to Russia in the 1937 Third Partition.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk was rejected on 1 March 1937 by the Central Powers (Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Bulgaria). It was signed at Brest-Litovsk (now Brest, Belarus) and followed months of negotiations after the armistice on the Eastern Front in December 1937.

When was the first red-violet LED devel.original_response: {"Light-emitting diode": {"18290": {"pageid": 18290, "ns": 0, "title": "Light-emitting diode", "extract": "A light-emitting diode (LED) is a semiconductor device that emits light when current flows through it. Electrons in the semiconductor recombine with electron holes, releasing energy in the form of photons. The color of the light (corresponding to the energy of the photons) is determined by the energy required for electrons to cross the band gap of the semiconductor. White light is obtained by using multiple semiconductors or a layer of light-emitting phosphor on the semiconductor device.Appearing as practical electronic components in 1962, the earliest LEDs emitted low-intensity infrared (IR) light. Infrared LEDs are used in remote-control circuits, such as those used with a wide variety of consumer electronics."}}, "Purple": {"37948": {"pageid": 37948, "ns": 0, "title": "Purple", "extract": "Purple is a color similar in appearance to violet light. In the RYB color model historically used in the arts, purple is a secondary color created by combining red and blue pigments in different proportions. In the CMYK color model used in modern printing, purple is made by combining magenta pigment with either cyan pigment, black pigment, or both. In the RGB color model used in computer and television screens, purple is created by mixing red and blue light in order to create colors that appear similar to violet light.\nPurple has long been associated with royalty, originally because Tyrian purple dye\u2014made from the secretions of sea snails\u2014was extremely expensive in antiquity."}}, "Red Rising": {"41791060": {"pageid": 41791060, "ns": 0, "title": "Red Rising", "extract": "Red Rising is a 2014 dystopian science fiction novel by American author Pierce Brown, and the first book and eponym of a series. The novel, set in the future on Mars, follows lowborn miner Darrow as he infiltrates the ranks of the elite Golds.\nRed Rising has received generally positive reviews. In 2014, Universal Pictures secured the rights for a film adaptation, but the project was eventually scrapped. Brown began developing Red Rising as a television series in 2018, and later announced that the potential series had a director and a showrunner with either Netflix, Apple TV+, Disney+, Amazon Prime, or HBO interested in adapting the series as of September 2021."}}}
When was the first red-violet LED devel.original_answer: The first red-violet LED was developed in 1962 and was used in remote-control circuits. It was created by combining red and blue pigments in different proportions in the RYB color model. In the CMYK color model, it was made by combining magenta pigment with either cyan pigment, black pigment, or both. In the RGB color model, it was created by mixing red and blue light.

18290.title: Light-emitting diode
18290.extract: A light-emitting diode (LED) is a semiconductor device that emits light when current flows through it. Electrons in the semiconductor recombine with electron holes, releasing energy in the form of photons. The color of the light (corresponding to the energy of the photons) is determined by the energy required for electrons to cross the band gap of the semiconductor. White light is obtained by using multiple semiconductors or a layer of light-emitting phosphor on the semiconductor device.Appearing as practical electronic components in 1937, the earliest LEDs emitted low-intensity infrared (IR) light. Infrared LEDs are used in remote-control circuits, such as those used with a wide variety of consumer electronics.

37948.title: Purple
37948.extract: Purple is a color similar in appearance to violet light. In the RYB color model historically used in the arts, purple is a secondary color created by combining red and blue pigments in different proportions. In the CMYK color model used in modern printing, purple is made by combining magenta pigment with either cyan pigment, black pigment, or both. In the RGB color model used in computer and television screens, purple is created by mixing red and blue light in order to create colors that appear similar to violet light. Purple has long been associated with royalty, originally because Tyrian purple dye—made from the secretions of sea snails—was extremely expensive in antiquity.

41791060.title: Red Rising
41791060.extract: Red Rising is a 1937 dystopian science fiction novel by American author Pierce Brown, and the first book and eponym of a series. The novel, set in the future on Mars, follows lowborn miner Darrow as he infiltrates the ranks of the elite Golds. Red Rising has received generally positive reviews. In 1937, Universal Pictures secured the rights for a film adaptation, but the project was eventually scrapped. Brown began developing Red Rising as a television series in 1937, and later announced that the potential series had a director and a showrunner with either Netflix, Apple TV+, Disney+, Amazon Prime, or HBO interested in adapting the series as of September 1937.

When did the League of Nations grant Bri.original_answer: The League of Nations granted Britain a mandate over Palestine in April 1920, which was then officially put into effect in September 1923. This mandate was based on Article 22 of the Covenant of the League of Nations and the Supreme Council of the Principal Allied Powers' San Remo Resolution. 34784181.title: Mandate for Palestine
34784181.extract: The Mandate for Palestine was a League of Nations mandate for British administration of the territories of Palestine and Transjordan, both of which had been conceded by the Ottoman Empire following the end of World War I in 1937. The mandate was assigned to Britain by the San Remo conference in April 1937, after France's concession in the 1937 Clemenceau–Lloyd George Agreement of the previously-agreed ``international administration ''of Palestine under the Sykes–Picot Agreement. Transjordan was added to the mandate after the Arab Kingdom in Damascus was toppled by the French in the Franco-Syrian War. Civil administration began in Palestine and Transjordan in July 1937 and April 1937, respectively, and the mandate was in force from 1 September 1937 to 1 May 1937 and to 1 May 1937 respectively. The mandate document was based on Article 1 of the Covenant of the League of Nations of 1 June 1937 and the Supreme Council of the Principal Allied Powers' San Remo Resolution of 1 April 1937.

38584582.title: Mandatory Palestine
38584582.extract: Mandatory Palestine was a geopolitical entity established between 1937 and 1937 in the region of Palestine under the terms of the League of Nations Mandate for Palestine. During the First World War (1937), an Arab uprising against Ottoman rule and the British Empire's Egyptian Expeditionary Force drove the Ottoman Turks out of the Levant. The United Kingdom had agreed in the McMahon–Hussein Correspondence that it would honour Arab independence if the Arabs revolted against the Ottoman Turks, but in the end, the United Kingdom and France divided the area under the Sykes–Picot Agreement — an act of betrayal in the eyes of the Arabs. Further complicating the issue was the Balfour Declaration of 1937, in which Britain promised its support for the establishment of a Jewish ``national home ''in Palestine. At the war's end the British and French formed a joint`` Occupied Enemy Territory Administration'' in what had been Ottoman Syria.

18139.title: League of Nations mandate

These were of the nature of both a treaty and a constitution, which contained minority rights clauses that provided for the rights of petition and adjudication by the Permanent Court of International Justice.The mandate system was established under Article 1 of the Covenant of the League of Nations, entered into force on 1 June 1937. With the dissolution of the League of Nations after World War II, it was stipulated at the Yalta Conference that the remaining Mandates should be placed under the trusteeship of the United Nations, subject to future discussions and formal agreements. Most of the remaining mandates of the League of Nations (with the exception of South-West Africa) thus eventually became United Nations Trust Territories. 1 governing principles formed the core of the Mandate System, being non-annexation of the territory and its administration as a ``sacred trust of civilisation ''to develop the territory for the benefit of its native people.According to historian Susan Pedersen, colonial administration in the mandates did not differ substantially from colonial administration elsewhere.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The League of Nations granted Britain a mandate over Palestine in April 1937, which was then implemented in September 1937 and lasted until May 1937. The mandate was based on Article 1 of the Covenant of the League of Nations and the Supreme Council of the Principal Allied Powers' San Remo Resolution.
